Some interesting characters, with great entertaining and funny action scenes.  The story is a bit convoluted, and perhaps over-the-top at times.  It didn't jump the shark, but it was getting close to that point.  It's not all that memorable, other than the fact that the story is really out there.
It fun, real and emotional to watch. Best movie to date.

Absolutely the worst movie I have every seen in my entire life.  Over 2 hours that I'll never get back.  Are the people that have rated this highly real people?  I suspect many are bots or paid to give it a good rating.   If you enjoy quality cinema, don't waste your time or money on this trash.
If it hadn't been nominated for so many Oscars, there's no way I would have watched the whole movie.
This film is a powerful trip everyone can enjoy safely, without taking any acid.
This is a film that film people might like, but not even a film that film people are supposed to like is good enough if it is a mess, which is to say that this film is sort of like this sentence.
A modern-day Matrix and worthy of being seen multiple times to unravel all the mystery and messages within.

It was bizarrely entertaining and very thought provoking.
I felt many emotions.

Whiplash editing, episodic martial arts displays, and 135 word per minute dialog resolve mercifully into improved family relationships in the final few minutes.  The hinted Pan-Universe perils are neither described nor addressed.
Make sure you take your LSD before watching this horrible dumb movie!

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is a visually stunning and thought-provoking film that explores the nature of reality and the interconnectedness of all things. The film follows a middle-aged woman named Mei who discovers that she is a multiverse-hopping warrior tasked with saving the universe from destruction.

The film's creative team, including directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, create a vivid and surreal world that is both mesmerizing and unsettling. The film's themes of identity, loss, and the nature of existence are explored with nuance and depth.

In addition to its philosophical musings, the film also features thrilling action sequences and a standout performance from lead actress Michelle Yeoh. Overall, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is a must-see for fans of science fiction and mind-bending cinema.
Lots to think and talk about after seeing this movie and lots of satire too.

One of only two movies my wife and I have ever walked out of. I believe there is a conspiracy by the Academy as a result of them being accused of neglecting actors,  based on color or origin, are hitting back at us  by voting this ridiculous movie as Oscar worthy.
Lovely plotline, crazy storyline, thoroughly enjoyable.
I loved the exploration of multiple realities.
Bizarre, hard to follow, multiple disjointed story lines and a thrown in "message" at the end in an effort to manipulate the audience & tug at their heart strings.  Totally overrated.

So, instead of all these crazy raving reviews that everyone is typing out because it's cool to like this movie, I'm going to give you a real and honest review. 

Firstly, this movie IS NOT BAD. In fact this movie is REALLY good! I really enjoyed it, the storyline and concept are very unique and the acting was amazing. A round of applause for this movie is absolutely deserved and it's worth watching. 

With that said, some scenes are unecessary and can confuse some people. There's some filler scenes that I didn't feel served any purpose, or were too long-drawn out. 

Over all great movie, I would recommend it.

This movie is a big fat yes. It's fun and engaging, deeply touching, and not only appreciates the art of film, but pushes the boundaries of what we expect from cinema. It's art AND entertainment. Most movies do one, this one does both extremely well.
Nothing nowhere all over the place. Profound cynicism meets sentimentality in a comic strip derived from other comic strips. This is a bad film rescued only by strong acting.

Terrible movie. I had hoped for the best (with all the hype I have heard about it). But trying to watch it today (one day before the Oscars) I gave up very early. What in the world was going on? I stayed for about 20 minutes, then left the theater. It should not take longer than that to engage with a supposedly good movie. If this wins the Academy Award's best movie, somebody sees something I did not see.

I'm a fan of Yeoh but this seemed like a hot mess. The writers in the alternate universe genre seem to think it means they can do whatever ridiculous thing they want, but it just makes it frenetic, not good entertainment.
It was very interesting, entertaining, but bizarre.

I went in wanting to really like it. I think I would have liked it better if the entire movie was the rocks talking to each other.  The acting was superb. The photography was awesome.  There were many disturbing things that I won't be able to unsee.  I have lost brain cells just trying to write this review.  Bye.
Hideous movie! 2 hours of my life totally wasted!
Nonsensical, I couldn't make it all the way through it. Don't waste your time.
I just do not get this film. Endless dull fight sequences and er…more endless dull fight sequences. Baffling.
Honestly don't get the hype - very boring
The movie is horrible, makes no sense and don't know why I watched till the end. Don't get why it has received so many accolades.

I'm sorry, I didn't understand this movie, it was too complicated and I got lost.  After 45 minutes I had to turn it off, it was making me dizzy.  11 Oscar nominations, really?  Maybe it's not for anyone in my age bracket then.  If you're over 50, you might want to give this a miss.

Had to digest this multiverse masterpiece by seeing it (at least) 3 times. All the little nuggets about intergenerational gaps, trauma and healing are so rich and fulfilling. When other Hollywood multiverse storylines like Dr. Strange and Ant Man failed us, EEAAO broke all molds and exceeded all expectations.
Clever story. Excellent performance from the masterful and experienced cast. And some of the fight scenes with their quirky approach were just perfect.
Despite a few scenes that didn't settle well with me, it was a brilliant film.

Difficult movie to watch with many frenetic scenes amalgamated into a thread leading to peace and harmony among an immigrant family. The major theme that our universe depends on a bagel hole and asshole( you will know what I mean by this when movie seen) is way too much for me.

Seriously people drove to the theater,  spent money on this,  then spent over 2 hours,  came out and said this was a great film?

This movie was beyond stupid,  and about 2 hours too long.  

Maybe the first 15 minutes were OK, when it seemed like they maybe had a plot.  Then it just goes off the rails,  and tries spend the next 2 hours trying to confuse you,  or show off dumb effects,  or just be goofy for no reason. 

I cannot believe this movie got so much praise.  Do not waste your time on this.

every new film/series is just a reminder, that we've barely scratched the surface in the infinite possibilities of storytelling and who knows what great new film/series is coming next... to make us feel even more tiny in this vast world of cinema.

been wanting to write a review for this since long ago but I couldn't really frame what I had to say for it up until now when I rewatched it today.

this film is as absurd as it can be in it's presentation, and that's a good thing. filmmakers are afraid to tap into weird and absurd things nowadays because of the possible financial losses. which makes this film feel really fresh in it's concept, it's storytelling, it's action, it's humour, everything is a result of peak imagination from the writer-directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert.

Michelle Yeoh. Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, James Hong. Jamie Lee Curtis, each and everyone in the cast is so good that there is not a single loose thread in the acting. they're all just perfect.

the story, phew. I can't really describe it to you but just to summarize, it's essentially a story about a mother who is a failure but doesn't want her daughter to be the same, but even if she's a failure, it doesn't matter because it does not change the fact that she is always gonna be her daughter and nothing in this vast multiverse can change that unconditional love a mother has for her child. michelle yeoh literally travels the entire multiverse to save her daughter and is stubborn (as she should be) in not letting her precious child go.

I didn't think this film would manage to make me cry when I stepped into the theatres to watch it for the first time. but so happened the first and, lo and behold, even after rewatching it today, I cried. the film manages to tap into every human emotion possible and makes you feel things. makes me happy, sad, angry, surprised, bitter and so much more.

the aspect which I loved the most? the editing. if this film hadn't been edited the way it has been. I think it wouldn't be able to achieve the status it has achieved as of now. It's so good, it's mind-boggling. I will try my best to recreate some of this in the future if I can because this film really opens up a lot of editing techniques which I've rarely seen before.

just watch this guys, it might become your favourite film of the year. a huge shoutout to A24 for producing this risky project and releasing it before the over-hyped Doctor Strange: Multiverse of Madness which, let's be honest, was barely about the multiverse and straight up disappointing.
Although this movies has may accolades and award nominations, I personally did not see it so worthy of that praise.
Very erratic and confusing.  Plan on leaving your subtitles on.  I don't see what the fuss is about - I have yet to make it all the way through this film.

I found this movie to be incredibly difficult to watch and follow. It was challenging to understand the dialogue (even with closed captioning on). I don't get the hype. I would have turned off sooner but wAtched until the end as I kept thinking the plot would reveal itself. It's chaotic and erratic. Do not recommend.
Interestingly bizarre

A movie about the search for meaning and self should not be more confusing than the search itself. Acting terrific. A zillion ideas, gimmicks, inventions, etc. Not much evidence of effort to select the best or most necessary. Hey, that's clever. Let's throw it all in instead of making choices.
Best movie of the year, beyond original & just so fun to watch. You found yourself laughing, being sooo confused, and crying all in these amazing film
One of the best movies I've ever seen! Definitely recommend seeing it in theaters if possible.

¡Así se construye el verdadero multiverso! Única y diferente a cualquier otra que haya visto antes. La historia es compleja y desafiante, tiene múltiples capas y elementos que se entrelazan perfectamente para crear una narrativa fascinante.

La actuación de Michelle Yeoh es impresionante. Su capacidad para mostrar diferentes emociones y facetas de su personaje es realmente asombrosa. Ella es la columna vertebral de la película y se roba la atención cada vez que aparece en pantalla.

Lo que realmente me encantó es la forma en que la muestran el tema de la realidad y las dimensiones. Es una reflexión cruda sobre cómo nuestras elecciones pueden influir en nuestro destino y el de aquellos que nos rodean. Además de abordar el tema de la depresión, la maternidad, los lazos familiares y la identidad.

Sin duda es una película a la que se le puede dar muchas lecturas.

One of the worst oscar nominated films we ever saw (Banshees was another one).  Who votes for these films....Just bizarre with very little plot done by good actors.  I'm embarrased to say we payed money for this.  Really bad movie all the way through.

We were curious about this apparently popular movie, couldn't make to the theater and didn't want to subscribe to Showtime, so we forked out $20 online to buy this movie. Beginning to watch on a 45" home TV, much of the dialogue was unintelligible. Clicked on captions. Movie appeared to be total fantasy, fast action, fast talking (in at least two languages), and total chaos. Jamie Lee Curtis--So what? My wife fell asleep after 5 minutes, and I clung to high hopes that I'd be drawn in. Alas, I could not stand this movie and turned it off after half an hour.

Everything is perfect. This will be a legend Everywhere. All at once combined makes an uncomfortable but nice experience.
A24 never disappoints me.

You'll either love it or hate it. The mostly Asian cast will throw people off; people won't relate or still have a bias towards Asians. The weirdness can be overpowering and jarring as well. However, if you focus on the mother, her relationship with her daughter, and her husband, things will start to make sense. It's an existential crisis reimagined as an alternate-universe adventure, filled with Buddhist and Christian themes of love, forgiveness, and karma affecting a working class Asian American immigrant family.

Just an amazing film and experience. A super creative story with great action and Cinematography. You can just feel the passion behind this project, all the emotion expressed in this film.....just amazing.
It starts out okay then turns into a headache inducing mess.

Finally saw "Everything, everywhere, all at one." Hated it. To me it's the longest one-line joke ever with the joke being on everything Hollywood that it ruthlessly made fun of, on the viewers who actually though that "nothing matters" was the "message," and on Hollywood elites who will reward it on Sunday to the snickers of its creators.

Mildly funny in areas it was a tiresome, tedious, self-indulgent and often boring film. I couldn't wait for it to be over. The metaphors were ridiculously heavy-handed (shoving an IRS award up your ass will transport you to another universe where you can gather special powers). I also thought it was poorly acted.

I had to give it only 1 star to put it in context with the fantasy/science fiction films of the past.

It has a very basic disjointed plot and is far too long for the content. The special effects are abysmal and very repetitive and so become tiring.

The human interest element is weak compared to the best SF movies of the past.

If you are looking for a "Chinese" film to provide balance to the Oscars then to be fair this may well be the best available.

Lots of funny moments, but it can get a bit too silly.  It was a little over the top for my wife at times but I was on-board.  The emotional moments are totally worth it.

The editing, the acting, the visuals, the whole everythingness of it, is great, this movie is fresh in many ways, it could have been another coming-of-age drama but it took a turn, and we are thankful for it. Someone said "a perfectly calibrated assault on the senses" about this movie, and I agree.
I don't get all the hype. I was expecting greatness all I got was eh. 🤔🤷

I think this is what a multiverse should look like. Although the main storyline might be cliche, but I think how it showed each universe was interesting and definitely memorable. Who will forget the sausage hands and the rocky conversation by the cliff?

EEAAO is my favorite film!!! I saw it in the theaters 3 times. Every viewing revealed new revelations. It meant everything to me to have such positive Asian representation up on the screen. I love that it was a story focused on an immigrant family and a mother and daughter relationship. It is funny, poignant, and moving. Ultimately, it is about the power of love and the ability to adapt and change. I am rooting 117% for EEAAO sweep at the Oscars!!!

A well executed glimpse into the human experience. Playing out like a vivid dream that seems nonsensical on the surface, this film offers keen viewers a journey deep into the human psyche through the exploration of abstract concepts like existentialism, depression, and the power of relationship. Unexpectedly mind-blowing.

I see the appeal of this movie but it left a bagel-hole in my soul. The pacing was kept at a good pace, appropriately balancing exposition, action, and character-development for the most part; although the plot slowed down too much in a couple different story-lines. It's generally well-produced, well-acted, and well-written--with a few plot holes still left in--but the narrative is rather self-indulgent and promotes a vacuous philosophy. The writers/directors unsuccessfully deaden their nihilistic bent with non-ironic, melodramatic sentimentality that rings hollow to the ears after all the pontificating that came before. The ultimate ideology of the movie undermines any gravitas or truthfulness of its final moments and its attempted rescue out of meaninglessness.
Quite honestly, I tried 3 times to watch this film, and made it through about half an hour before giving up on it.

That's about 30 minutes of my life I'll never get back. Could be worse though, I could have watched the entire thing. Does it surprise me this movie is a top contender for this years best movie Oscar....nope. The only question left is whether or not this box office bomb will be seen by more, or less people than this years Oscars.

Understandably, this movie isn't for everyone but if it's for you, it's REALLY for you.  This is my favorite movie now.  The acting is brilliant.  The story-telling is madly creative.  It tackles generational trauma, a lifetime of regrets, nihilism, AND offers hope while waving hotdog fingers at your face.  Watch out for how the meaning of "Nothing matters" shifts in the story.  *chef's kiss*

I watch films for entertainment and education. I didn't get much of either with this film. I'm a senior citizen and not into Kung Fu movies which occupies an inordinate amount of its screen time. I do like science fiction and time travel flicks but Everywhere was too confusing for my tastes. The acting (as little as there was) was excellent but to me it didn't save the movie from over 2 hours of boredom. I really wanted to like it since so many critics and viewers seem to love it but it just didn't work. Maybe 45 minutes less of Kung Ku would have helped.

This film hooked me in the beginning; loved the acting and story of the kind and patient husband with the impossibly tightly wound wife.  Also the visit to the IRS agent played by Jamie Lee Curtis was great, including her collection of desktop awards bearing a strong resemblance to a sex toy called a "butt plug".  I wish the whole thing had kept my interest as well as the 1st 1/3 of the film.  Acting was fine, even exceptional.  It did drag at times and I lost the plot too; and it has a feel good ending.  Sadly the who thing was tainted by what I consider an obscene scene involving two "bad guys" who gain power by jumping rear end first onto the butt plugs and fighting with these things explicitly hanging out from their rears.  This was not funny, nor did it advance the plot nor make the film more entertaining.  It only offends viewers with any kind of moral sensibilities and is shocking enough to make me want to "unsee" it.  Its disturbing enough to rank (almost) with John Waters' torturing death onscreen of a chicken in "Pink Flamingos".   Nice story, but nothing new at all, stretched into way too long a movie and marred by the aforementioned scene.
Unclear if the creator of the movie wanted it to be comic, drama or action.  The story line is broken and frankly does not have a plot to follow.
it's work to watch with the frenetic scene switches. Plot lines didn't really grab me despite their interesting potential. I wanted to like it but to no avail.

There are movies which you take along in your life, which impacts the way you think and /or broaden your horizons. This is one of them. There are so many layers in this movie 
all happening 
all at once 
All the time.
This movie has introduce cinema to lot of bath breaking new concepts, which will be cherished and inspired from in years to come.

A twisted movie filled with all sorts of metaphors and philosophic advice. The acting was superb! Who doesn't love Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan! I thought the movie a tad too long but definitely worth seeing,

Great acting could not redeem it.  I like the star and wanted to really like this movie as I love sci-fi and fantasy and the multiverse concept was appealing.  On hearing the hype about awards, I mistakenly assumed it would be good.    But this movie is two hours of 90% visual chaos alleviated at a few points by the theme of love.  It is punctuated with gross and bad-taste imagery.  It is a painful and ridiculous execution of a good concept but the movie makers had no true intuition about the subject matter.  The experience is a bad shock unless your nervous system is adapted to a chaotic drug trip-type experience.  That this movie is receiving such high makes me fear for humanity and think Earth is, as some traditions indicate, a non-scared planet and star of sorrow.
Um dos melhores filmes ja lançados na historia do cinema

Don't listen to Katherine G. She is a liar. It's not one long fight scene. They literally turn into rocks and talk to each other and people have hot dog hands! Don't tell me that's not at least somewhat entertaining. I bet a high percentage of the people that said, "I didn't understand this movie" sent their children to conversion therapy.
Yes, the effects were very good, but the story itself seems pointless, drawn out and sometimes poorly acted.
The action sequence and the way the story was told were ingenious.
One of the best visual experiences I've seen in my life!!

One of the movies of the year, Michel Yoh is amazing, script is intelligent, how they filled l filmed it with practical effects was just ingenious and the plot still fresh and understandable which is crazy considering the title of the movie. Well worth it
Hated it. Two hours of violence and insanity. In shock that this could be considered best of the year.
Not what I expected.  All the fantasy stuff was too long, and a bit silly.

This movie is dark and messy, has a Matrix-y sensibility, but instead of a cyber-verse it's about an alpha-verse and the endless other-verses that might possibly have taken place. It has astounding editing and effects, switching between universes at the speed of light, and over all a tale of a mother-daughter and wife-husband and young love is revealed through the chaos of verse-jumping. It's cool to see, but be prepared for something completely non-linear. Also has some wry existential humor. Maybe I liked it more than I think.

EEAAO is the best movie in decades. A few multiverse movies are out there, but EEAAO delivered the vision and idea of what it truly represents. It uses the multiverse as a backdrop to tell a story of generational trauma, and love and acceptance are what we need to move forward. Beautifully done.
First 15 minutes was good, rest of the film was rubbish! I stopped watching before the end.
Confusing, didn't like the movie at all. Would not recommend it at all. Worse movie I have ever seen.

Had to see it because it was nominated for best picture.  Wanted to leave well before the half-way point.  The mother-daughter story had some promise.  The struggle of a small business against the IRS was funny, but the multiverse nonsense took over the entire movie and reduced it to a heap of fast-paced hooey.
I found the less I tried to understand what was going on in the film, the more I enjoyed it.  So if you're watching it for the first time, just sit back and enjoy the ride.
It was a very disturbing movie and not quite sure I even understood it!!!!
Maybe I didn't get it at all. Maybe it was just the crazy s*t  story and the Jackie Chan karate but really… slept 2 times before finishing it.

Very cool effects, but the movie seems to drop the ball in the 2nd half.
In a market saturated with surreal high-concept movies with a bit of comedy mixed in,
this movie is Family Guy.
Just too silly for most fans of the genre.
Several wows, but not enough to make it worth a 2nd watch.
The relationship  between the daughter and mother is so true to the Asian culture that I’m surprised that this movie is so popular in the US. It was fast paced and the acting was great!
Inventive. Smart. Profound. Profane.

Not sure what all the hype is about this movie, I found it boring, with a ton of gorry violence for no reason, most bizarre meaningless plot, if you want to make a point about zen or "being in the moment" and all things are simple but important, or whatever the messge was supposed to be, it was lost on me and my family; there would have been a million better ways to tell the story or make the point than this vehicle...
The Daniels make The Matrix.
The most bizarre movie ever
Horrible. Zero continuity, boring, confusing, not funny, disturbing, gross, messy. Worst movie ever.
Great movie to never have seen, bad luck that we did!

It was WORK! but most of the good stuff takes work, no? 
Hints of "La-La-land" and "It's a Wonderful Life." Like rafting down the Colorado River in the old days, during spring thaw, after taking some industrial strength acid. But the end is so simple and true, so touching and gentle after a wild ride. And as a Queen once sang, "Nothing really matters..."
its was amazing, deep and emotional.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is an undescribable movie.
Every genre, every emotion, every part. There is only one Michelle Yeoh, and from seeing her doing her own stunts in Police Story 3: Supercop (1992), she was instantly my favourite Hong Kong export. This is like no other movie and it is like every movie, based on nothing before, but without other movies previously it would never exist. 11/10 🍿

I heard good reviews about this. And usually when reviews that are this good, it is bound to be overhyped. But I gave it a try anyhow to see if it lives up to the hype. Not going to lie, it started off kind of messy, and I had a hard time following the story switching between the english and chinese language. The scenes in the first half of the movie appeared incoherent and it was hard to understand what was going on. But then I discovered that this incoherence was consistent, like some mathematical constant and came to realization that maybe I should not approach this movie with logic and I should not try so hard to understand it, but rather let the movie take you in for the ride and get into it for the sensation of it all and see where it goes. And oh my, how it delivered. I wasn't expecting such an epic emotional rollercoaster experience, even with all the crazy over the top things happening on screen, it blended very well together. It literally included everything, everywhere, all at once that you ever wanted in a movie. This was a masterpiece of a movie. Instant timeless classic, and topics touched upon that are very relevant for our times. This also shows you that representation matters! It gives us a whole range of new and interesting perspective and content we never knew we wanted! My compliments for the script writers and producers for giving us this gem of a movie and it certainly lived up to the hype and more!
Very unique story, great visuals throughout.

The best part of this film is the opening shot where we witness a family, laughing and jumping up and down as they watch something, through a mirror on the wall, paired by some clever chords from Son Lux's overall meh score. Beyond that opening shot though, is a VERY meh movie. The idea of this film is incredibly creative and very ambitious. To the editor for splicing together so many multiverse shots and to the Daniels for writing and directing said shots, I commend them. However, to do a multiverse film and simultaneously address the meaning of life in a profound way…I don't think they quite pulled it off. The character of Joy represents our modern society and every classic young adult today that feels hopeless and doesn't have another deep thought afterward. This is supposedly a film about a mother and daughter who can't quite understand each other or love one another well. To properly resolve such a broken relationship, the emotional scene at the end would sound something like this: Evelyn saying, "I'm sorry. I know that you hate your life and that things are hard. I don't want that for you. I love you. We can make this relationship work and try to help each other out," with Joy replying, "I love you too, mom. And I'm sorry for everything before. Yes, let's do this. Let's make this work." Instead, we get Evelyn saying, "We can do whatever we want. Nothing matters," with Joy replying, "This is so embarrassing." This is not a character arc where flaws are conquered and a compromise is made between two colliding personalities. This is simply a brief addressing of an existing pain, followed by a sarcastic ignoring of it. I also do not understand the hype over the acting. Don't get me wrong, Ke Huy Quan plays his part perfectly, is quite endearing, and the best character in the film. However, his role is not a hard one to play nor demanding of an Oscar. Stephanie Hsu plays her part very well and has the most depth to her character, but the character is poorly written, over-ridden with attitude and spite and robbed of the sympathy and empathy that would make an audience root for her. Michelle Yeoh does not stun in a complex, awe-inspiring role. She does just fine in the role of a mom who gets to be a comic-book hero for a day. And Jamie Lee Curtis does not transform herself into a SAG-award-winning IRS agent. She simply is her funny, goofy Jamie Lee Curtis self making us laugh because she's Jamie Lee Curtis. Yes, the comedic elements of this movie and some of the jokes and gags that come around are hilarious and quite clever. But, if Ke Huy Quan needed me to commit an impossibility to travel to an alternate universe, for me, it would not be to confess my love for Jamie Lee Curtis or to stick a cone up my ass, but to say with confidence that Everything Everywhere All At Once is the best picture of the year.

I must say the first time I watched this movie I was at first disappointed because I had heard very good things about it, and in the first hour or so I was worried it would just be a rather generic sci-fi multiverse movie, but as the story and characters continued to develop I was increasingly invested. The multiverse concept lets the viewer understand characters on a deeper level in a rather unique way that I haven't seen utilized in many other multiverse movies (which tend to use alternate realities simply as cool backdrops). Since my first viewing, I've watched the movie as least 3 more times and each time I end it bawling. I will admit sometimes the humor can be a little bit excessive, but I don't think at all that it takes away from the emotional experience.

Prepare to have your mind blown and your heartstrings pulled in all directions with Everything Everywhere All at Once, the wildest ride of 2022. The Daniels have outdone themselves with their inventive extravaganza that takes you on a journey through multiple universes, each more bizarre than the last. Michelle Yeoh's kick-ass performance as a time-traveling laundromat manager is a force to be reckoned with, and the film's exploration of family dynamics and existential crises adds a layer of depth to the bonkers surface. At times, the film may overwhelm you with its sheer amount of creativity, but fear not - successive second winds are sure to follow. In the end, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a wonderfully weird and moving film that will leave you with a newfound appreciation for the power of family, no matter how complicated and messy it may be. Don't miss out on this volcanic eruption of creative ideas - it's like nothing you've ever seen!

The concept is worthy--the idea of how even the smallest decision we make has a profound effect on the path our loves may take.  But this was exhausting, and now I feel guilty for not thinking this film is astounding, fantastic, etc.

There was so much hype surrounding this movie, and it delivered. What a title, how do you even attempt to live up to it?

Michelle Yeoh is incredible in this movie. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert wrote and directed together to bring a truly ambitious and original concept to life. The story explores the nature of self and being through the story of one family, and the multiple lives they lead in the infinite multiverse, ultimately helping our hero find joy in her (meaningful/meaningless?) existence.

I'm not a huge fan of the multiverse in film, but this movie brings entirely new elements to the table, and the set of rules introduced to jumping from one universe to the next keeps everyone on their toes.

The value of the serious and silly is evident here and balanced in a way that is rarely done well. The filmmakers took on so much, and pulled it off so well.
My favorite movie of the year!!!

The greatest piece of cinematography I've seen in ages; maybe ever. A beautiful story with incredible acting and a crazy/fun/unique premise. I was on the edge of my seat the entire way through. The exciting action is only the cherry on top of the immaculately conflicting comedy and heartbreak. This wholesome albeit not so family friendly film is a must watch! The Daniel's have earned my respect and anticipation and I am now going to go watch as many A24 films as I can.

What a load of incoherent self-indulgent tosh. Apparently written entirely to pander to the egos of the special effects department. If there's a plot in there it's pretty much incomprehensible. I think there's an evil being intent on messing up all the universes, but in our main story - is there a main story? - she's quite nice. Whereas our main heroine is not very nice in the original story but ends up OK after beating up dozens of people in various different universes. But I wouldn't swear to any of that! I suspect that all the awards for this movie are because no-one in the industry dares to say out loud : "this Emperor has no clothes".
Didn’t get it.  Can’t believe it was nominated for anything.

Truly the BEST movie of the year!!! Mind-bending and creative, funny, edge of your seat exciting, and PROFOUNDLY moving.  Reminds one of how thrilling film art can be and how precious it is to be alive.  It should win everything (all at once!) because of it's breathtakingly originality  and the superlative performances across the board. Whatever happens, the message of this movie is what matters. See it!
It's a little bit difficult to understand but it's so much fun to watching. It's full of beautiful imagery, great acting, comedy, and the best choreography I've seen in years.
It was absurd, uncomfortable, chaotic, and sometimes too much.... But it tackled deep family issues and at the end it made me cry.

What a fantastic return-to-the-big-screen vehicle for the talented Ke Huy Quan, another amazing showcase of Michelle Yeoh's endless talent, and a great cameo role for Jamie Lee Curtis. Stephanie Hsu ate up scenery in her endless stream of wildly fashionable costumes and dry delivery as the insidious yet oddly likable Jobu Tupaki. 

Everything, Everywhere, All At Once effectively delivered a ridiculous amount of ideas and visuals compacted into a refreshing theme that was both enlightening and heartwarming. It seemed to be saying; 'Your limitless potential is only buried under your fear of being out of the ordinary' while also pairing it with the power of kindness.  It's an important message in a very real era of division, distrust, and blind animosity amplified by the power of social media.

I waited on this one, not being completely roped in by overhyped reviews but once I finally sat down to view it I saw what all the hype was about.  I can't praise The Daniels enough for this entertaining gem.
Whacky and zany ride that delivers the best movie I've seen in a long time!

Overall, I found this movie difficult to follow and understand.  No doubt it falls in the category of "science fiction" but it may be far-reaching calling it a comedy.  In addition to the actors, credit the Cinematographer and Editor for visualizing a complex screenplay.  To be more effective, I felt that the storyline could have been anchored more often in the reality scenes so that viewers could more easily follow along.  Another movie, "The Matrix", also involved alternate realities but that film was easier to follow.  Everything, Everywhere, All at Once lives up to its title in a disappointing way.

This incredible cast pulls together what often borders on an impossibly nonsensical screenplay - truly, every single player is a fantastically grounding presence. At times the action is just absurd for the sake of it, too focussed on doing something outlandish to keep up steady, coherent pacing, but overall the thread strings together in a compelling way. You stay watching because you want to see these characters discover their own meaning and place within the chaos of experiences the movie plays out. Worth a watch, just be warned - it lives up to its title and then some.

One of my favorite type of movies/TV shows is about time travel... My other favorite type is about different dimensions and dimensional travel...

Imagine, for a moment, that you had made different life choices. You went LEFT instead of RIGHT. You decided not to GO TO that party. Or you said YES instead of NO. 

HOW different would your life be?

This movie, explores those possibilities. Despite some of the absurdism, this movie explores those choices you've made and the CONSEQUENCES of those actions...

Moderately entertaining and energetic cinema, but way too fast paced, as I found it difficult to enjoy any one scene as the film would zip from scene to scene feverishly. Stylistically, I realize that's the nature of this movie, but it would have been better to have at least a few slower scenes of exposition at the start to set the stage for the interdimensional plot points. A few great laugh out loud scenes, some great performances, but overall, this is a highly overrated film and how it nabbed so many Oscars is beyond me. This kind of reminds me of Birdman, years later I am wondering HOW that earned Best Picture. It is great to see films like this that aren't a franchise, remake or sequel, etc., and are at least trying to do something original.
A wild, crazy exploration of the multiverse, while still telling a gut-wrenching story of love and what it means to live as a small speck in the massive universe.

The breathless, unpunctuated title says it all: this film throws everything plus the kitchen sink at you to keep you overwhelmed, bewildered, and, most importantly, unable to think much about the stupidity of its premise for over 2 hours of ‘entertainment'. The filmmakers assume that younger American viewers require constant stimulation to watch a feature-length movie these days.  As a result, whatever might be worthwhile in this project is handcuffed to wildly over-elaborate – yet oddly unimpressive – special effects and martial arts displays in the ‘bunch of stuff that happens' category. It is like trying to follow someone telling you something serious about themselves during a loud, manic rock concert.

This film reflects Asian sensibilities, such as deferring to parental/social expectations to the point of losing one's selfhood, and all the foolishness about people having many other lives in alternate universes is based on reincarnation and the many lives one has lived before the present, from which one is carrying karmic baggage. So why not present these concepts intelligibly, instead of garbling everything with a myriad of cooked-up distractions?

Everything Everywhere All at Once takes you into a magical multidimensional journey through multiple lives of our main characters Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh) and Waymond Wang (Ke Huy Quan). The film boasts a seemingly long two and a half hour epoch of a film, but packed into it involves multiple lives and multiple messages worth your viewing. From Michelle Yeoh's exceptional (as always) performance and Ke Huy Quan's underdog of an unexpected comeback performance allows the film to sail into your heart and leave you thinking about the things that really matter in life. Personally, when I walked out of the theatre, I was awestruck. I loved every minute. I overheard a woman talking about the film, claiming she found no message. I am here to say that is not the case whatsoever. The film has multiple messages for the viewer to cling onto and relate to. Make sure you do not skip Ke Huy Quan's return to acting with this amazing epoch following a seemingly normal Chinese family in their multidimensional journey to find out what is important in life. A+ a must watch.

It's boring and terminally self induglent like endless million-notes-a-minute guitar shredding is - and i think the thing that really made it a difficult watch was that i just didn't care about any of the characters. On the upside - Jamie Lee Curtis is very watchable and turns in the performance of the film.

ENGLISH REVIEW
Everything Everywhere All at Once is a movie that is best experienced without knowing too much about it. In short, it follows a Chinese immigrant family dealing with tax issues and relationship problems, but it's so much more than that. The movie is a unique blend of originality, creativity, heart, and absurdity, with Michelle Yeoh's Evelyn and her daughter Joy (played by Hsu) at the center of the story. The relationship between Evelyn and Joy drives the narrative through its multiverse-spanning journey, with help from other characters like Waymond, Gong Gong, and Deirdre. Yeoh shines in her role as she portrays multiple versions of herself in an action-packed and emotionally charged performance. The movie is filled with weird and wonderful characters, situations, and lifestyles as the Daniels (the filmmakers) fully embrace the madness of the concept. Despite the absurdity, the movie never loses sight of the importance of family and provides a deep look at generational trauma, existentialism, and identity. The movie also takes the audience on an emotional journey, culminating in a tear-inducing finale. It's a truly impressive feat given the eccentric and outlandish nature of the movie, and in a time where audiences are craving originality, Everything Everywhere All at Once delivers with a fearless and nonconformist approach. It's a cinematic maverick that's bonkers, chaotic, and wild – a rare treat.

SPANISH REVIEW
Everything Everywhere All at Once es una película que se experimenta mejor sin saber demasiado al respecto. En resumen, sigue a una familia de inmigrantes chinos que se enfrenta a problemas fiscales y de pareja, pero es mucho más que eso. La película es una combinación única de originalidad, creatividad, corazón y absurdo, con Evelyn de Michelle Yeoh y su hija Joy (interpretada por Hsu) en el centro de la historia. La relación entre Evelyn y Joy impulsa la narrativa a través de su viaje que abarca varios universos, con la ayuda de otros personajes como Waymond, Gong Gong y Deirdre. Yeoh brilla en su papel al representar múltiples versiones de sí misma en una actuación llena de acción y carga emocional. La película está llena de personajes, situaciones y estilos de vida extraños y maravillosos, ya que los Daniels (los cineastas) aceptan por completo la locura del concepto. A pesar de lo absurdo, la película nunca pierde de vista la importancia de la familia y ofrece una mirada profunda al trauma generacional, el existencialismo y la identidad. La película también lleva a la audiencia a un viaje emocional, que culmina en un final que provoca lágrimas. Es una hazaña realmente impresionante dada la naturaleza excéntrica y extravagante de la película, y en un momento en que el público anhela la originalidad, Everything Everywhere All at Once ofrece un enfoque intrépido e inconformista. Es un inconformista cinematográfico que es loco, caótico y salvaje, un placer raro.

Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert (A.K.A Daniels) bring audiences a fascinating film about a Chinese immigrant who becomes entangled in a multiverse-spanning adventure after trying to do her taxes. BAFTA nominee Michelle Yeoh stars alongside Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, James Hong, and Jamie Lee Curtis in one of 2022's most exciting films.

‘Everything Everywhere All at Once' follows Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh), an overworked Chinese immigrant who runs a laundromat with her husband Waymond, while also dealing with the strained relationship she has with her daughter and her judgemental father. Amid juggling her personal issues, Evelyn must attend a meeting with the IRS to discuss her business' web of finances. However, what occurs during this meeting will change the course of Evelyn's life forever, taking her on a mammoth journey across the multi-verse that makes for one of A24's craziest films.

Even though ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once' is a film that features wacky, unpredictable action, Daniel Kwan and Daniel Schienert direct a film that, despite its crazy fight sequences is packed topfull of complex emotion. The directing duo bring audiences a film that manages to inject powerful emotions into some of the wackiest scenarios you'll ever see. Perhaps the film's ability to balance heart-wrenching sentiment, outrageous comedy and erratic action is what makes it such a unique film, even by A24's boundary-pushing standards. ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once' does carry a hefty runtime with its daring storyline, coming in at 139 minutes, even longer than this year's other multi-versal event, Sam Raimi's ‘Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness' which is only 126 minutes. However, unlike its Marvel counterpart, it audiences a more thorough insight into the world's many universes. We get to see universes where Evelyn (Yeoh) takes on careers like being a professional singer, acting and a Teppanyaki chef, as well as worlds where humanity evolved to have hot-dog fingers or places where life was never born, thus resulting in Joy (Hsu) and Evelyn taking on the form of rocks. This scene between Evelyn and Joy surprises viewers who will end up crying at two rocks engaging in a subtitled conversation about the complexity of life.

Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu both give magnificent performances and by the end of the film audiences will be excited for their next outing together, which as of May 2022, the pair have both been announced to star in the new Disney+ series ‘American Born Chinese'. Hsu's performance as both versions of Joy make you feel like you're watching two vastly different actors and makes for performance you can't draw yourself away from. Ke Huy Quan also delivers a brilliant turn as both versions of Waymond, one as a feeble and wimpy version of Evelyn's husband and the other as a skilled fighter and multi-verse traveller. However, the highlight of both Quan and Yeoh's performances comes towards the end of the film in which alternate versions of Waymond and Evelyn discuss what could've been in a scene that emanates films from acclaimed director Wong Kar Wai. Jamie Lee Curtis delivers a hilarious performance as Deidre and the alternate versions of the mundane IRS officer

Audiences are thrown in for an emotional rollercoaster when they sit down to watch ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once', dealing with themes of acceptance, divorce, love, and the complexity of mother/daughter relationships. So not only does the film deliver on it's promise of an ‘insane adventure', but also tugs at your heartstrings. The film is filled with top-notch craftsmanship, ranging from clever editing that elevates the project to another level and an impressive screenplay from Scheinert and Kwan. This is a film that isn't afraid to be unapologetically silly or ridiculous, and perhaps that's what makes is such a special film.

‘Everything Everywhere All at Once' is a film that puts a wacky and refreshingly unique spin on the idea of a multiverse, made popular by Marvel's ever-growing universe of films. Directing duo Daniels create a film that not only entertains with it's interesting and thought-provoking story, but also with its impressive technical factors and performances that will hopefully make it a contender in the 2022/23 awards season. The film joins the ranks of some of A24's best films, sitting on the same shelf as films like Greta Gerwig's 2017 coming-of-age film ‘Lady Bird', Mike Mills drama ‘C'mon C'mon and Ari Aster's terrifying horror ‘Midsommar'. Taking its audiences on a wild ride across the multiverse, ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once' takes its spot as one of 2022's best films already and brings a ground-breaking story to audiences across the world.

I watched "Everything Everywhere All at Once" recently. It is a very strange movie about multiple realities intersecting and affecting the entire universe. It is up to a middle-aged Chinese immigrant (Michelle Yeoh) to save the universe! Also involved is Jamie Lee Curtis as an overzealous IRS auditor! To me, it seemed like being in an overlong acid trip (although I have never taken LSD, it seemed like something one might experience on that drug!). So, I am not sure I can recommend this movie, except that Michelle Yeoh and especially Jamie Lee Curtis's performances are very good. I found the movie itself to be overstuffed, overlong and ultimately ridiculous. 5/1

Went in with high expectations, especially as someone who enjoys mindscrew media and nihilism, but this was a mess of a movie. The first 45 minutes telling the story of a struggling immigrant family had me engaged, despite the rather hamfisted misunderstood lesbian daughter drama, but as soon as they go to the IRS office, the entire movie goes off the rails and turns into a wacky kung-fu romp. I struggled to suspend my disbelief because the writing was so stereotypical that I just assumed they were going to pull back the veil to reveal they were parodying bad science fiction, but no, they spend two hours on this weak plot. Most frustratingly, Ke Huy Quan (Waymond) mumbles and rushes through most of his lines and switches frequently between Mandarin and English, making his frenzied explanations incoherent and hard to follow. This was an annoying and disappointing watch and I found myself constantly checking to see when it would be over.

Arriving maybe a bit too late to assert any kind of originality, this movie is saturated with homages, barmy humor, and overwhelming gonzo science concepts while also trying to communicate across larger themes of existentialism. A lot of it works, and a lot of it just comes off as someone thinking about why his life stinks while standing in the shower. For one, I just don't buy Michelle Yeoh's character. She fails to deliver the intended comedy in this story. Even if her reactions are meant to be those of an "everyman," I don't believe her performance. There is a rumor that they wanted Jackie Chan at first. With that knowledge, you can see how this character was almost tailor-made for him; he would have been glorious, and he could probably spice up those low-budget martial arts scenes they had. However, on the opposite end of the spectrum from Michelle is Ke Huy Quan. He is just marvelous and, in my view, carried the movie. In the end, the glitzy editing and too much stuff being thrown on screen dilute the movie. And with so much buildup, one might even expect something other than the simple principle of "Be good and find your own meaning." But alas, the movie spends too much time on the sausage finger gag. One of the Dans absolutely adored that joke.

I found this movie to be very intriguing and keeps you on edge and keeps you focused on the story. I loved the acting, and the representation the Asian community was getting with a majority Asian cast. This made it beam inclusion and relatability, and I think that's the reason people were so fond of this movie. I loved the symbolism they kept using, and how the movie touches on very serious topics. Additionally, they use humor as comedic relief every now and then to keep people engaged. One thing I wish it had is a little more clarity on some of the metaphors that they were trying to use. It did get a bit confusing at times, and I would get lost in where the plot was going. I think that might have been intentional, and that is what made it stand out so much. It was a movie that I wanted to watch again to make sure I fully grasped it, and I believe that's what makes it special.

As "Everything Everywhere All at Once" (2022 release; 139 min.) opens, we are introduced to Evelyn Quan, who along with her husband, runs a laundromat. For reasons unknown, the laundromat is being audited by the IRS, and a meeting with the IRS auditor does not go well. Then out of the blue, Evelyn's mind is taken over by her husband's alternative from the Alphaverse, one of apparently thousands of alternative universes out there... At this point we are 10 minutes into the movie.

Couple of comment: this is the latest from writers-producers-directors Daniel Kwam and Daniel Scheineret (a/k/a "the Danierls"). This is only their second feature length movie, after 2016's critically acclaimed "Swiss Army Man". Like that movie, in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" they bring a highly original premise and story line. Frankly, the plot is so off kilter that it doesn't even make any sense, nor need it be. Instead, one simply sits back and enjoys whatever is unfolding on the screen. Michelle Yeoh is outstanding as Evelyn. I didn't realize that the IRS auditor is played by Jamie Lee Curtis until the credits rolled. I don't know if others felt the same, but I felt a bit overwhelmed, if npot exhausted, by it all and I watched the entire movie over two equal parts on consecutive evenings. That does not mean that I didn't like the movie, let me be clear.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" was an unexpected box office hit during its US theatrical run that started last Spring, For whatever reason I just didn't feel drawn to it. Then earlier this week, it gathered an amazing 11 Oscar nominations, more than any other film, and I told myself I really needed to find out what the buzz was all about. I watched the film earlier this week (it's streaming on Showtime). Glad I did. If you are in the mood for truly something very different and uniquely original, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion.

First 20 minutes was fantastic, totally hooked me. Often that doesn't happen so I was settling in for a great movie. Ooof, after that first 20 minutes when the movie switched, the entire movie was awful. I kept thinking they would revert to the style of the first part of the movie. The story line being set up and the characters were off to a great start, sitting through the rest of the movie was painful, one of the worst movies I've ever seen.

The film is a sly parody of the Marvel Cinematic Universe's (MCU) "What If" series in its exploration of alternate realities, but quickly switches tracks to ground the narrative and its characters in our reality to explore many themes that are close to home. Chief of those themes is the importance of priorities, with filmmakers writing a good chunk of Evelyn's dialogue to emphasize her desperation on keeping the family business afloat while facing the consequences of her decisions. This is further explored in the early flashback scenes of Evelyn's and Waymond's relationship, the birth of their family business, and the birth of their daughter.

Throughout the film, filmmakers also allude to the importance of acceptance. We see this play out with Evelyn and her father, tiptoeing around the topic of her daughter dating another woman. This theme is also echoed by the constant shift in Waymond's personality, who alternates between his present non-masculine self, and his alternate reality personality who is a confident and skilled fighter, whom Evelyn falls deep in love with. The biggest thing Evelyn had to come to terms with throughout the film was accepting that she was burned out, that she couldn't shoulder all the family's responsibility on her own, and that it was okay for her to ask for help.

This leads to the other theme that was explored in the film - the strength to rely on others. Throughout the film, we see the effects of Evelyn shouldering everything on her own. We see everything around her starting to crumble, figuratively and literally. This eventually leads to her falling apart, not knowing what to do. These scenes contrast drastically with the final few scenes of the film where we see Evelyn happy, having those weights lifted from her shoulders.

One other theme that filmmakers chose to explore with this reality-bending film is the importance of facing reality. This is seen throughout the movie with the intercut scenes of the other realities, which Evelyn slowly begins running away to when things become too overwhelming for her. Eventually, with those realities beginning to fold into her own, she is forced to return to her reality to address what she has done and what she has to do.

This film is a wonderful exploration of both reality and alternate realities. Every scene is meaningful and well-paced, with a great blend of well-choreographed and whimsical action scenes. Despite being conceptually brilliant, the film's villain is plagued by the "MCU villain" problem, being two-dimensional in portrayal and dialog. Filmmakers had a golden egg in their hands with the concept of the film's big bad but failed to leverage more on her backstory to make her more relatable, especially to younger teenage audiences who could see themselves in the villain's shoes. What made it worse was the overwhelming contrast between the main character and the villain of the film, with the main character's performance and dialog outshining that of the villain. Nevertheless, the heart of the story remains clear and simple for audiences of most age groups to understand and appreciate. With a personal rating of 4.5/5, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a must-watch film for parents and teenagers alike, especially in theaters with the right audio and video formats.

The minute Waymond, the young patriarch of the Wang clan, starts his parkour across the family-owned laundromat, the viewer gets a glimpse of the impending frenetic multiverse that guides the movie for the next few hours, helping it live up to its title… it really was everything, everywhere, all at once.

Throughout the movie, the director quickly and sometimes confusingly trapses through familiar plot elements that will resonate, if the viewer can pull back the curtain of the hyperactive and manic effort from the characters at play. We get glimpses of family strife, parental discord, personal discontent, disappointment, resignation, joy, redemption. To this concern, viewers, please be warned, in an effort to stay in line with the quick moving story or to just relive some of the more bizarre twists, you may need to be prepared with a thumb or forefinger ready on the pause, rewind, go back 15 seconds button. One might offer that it, in fact, adds another level to the multiverse experience. In the end, the movie slows down enough to allow the viewer time to catch-up with the plot and message before the credits roll.

For some this movie will be an exciting ride, one in which the viewer will spend with their hands in the air, exhilarated at every quick twist and turn. Amazed at the intense action fight scenes, giggling at the absurd and over-the-top visual elements chosen for various alternate worlds. For others, it will lack the needed depth to stay connected to the characters and storyline, instead wishing they could opt for an alternate universe in which the viewer decided to skip the movie and catch-up on some streaming binge worthy show.

A Pat-Oh_Meter Review

First off, the title should be modified to say, "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once, Over and Over, and Way too Long." Although the run time is only two hours and 19 minutes, the repetitive nature of the film's multiverse, mad-cap action left me wishing the darn thing would end.

Sad to say, since my husband and I had looked forward to seeing this one. The performances were great. The multiverse concept intriguing. The fast-paced scenes and elaborate settings were amazing. My gosh, the shooting script must have been 400 pages.

But the point of this film, which is disguised as a sci-fi comedy, is essentially a dysfunctional family coming together to forgive. Plot-wise, that's about it, although the filmmakers kept hammering lines like "nothing matters" and "be kind" and "we're all small and stupid" and even the "F" word all by itself on screen for us to treasure. 

A mature Michelle Yeoh stars as the overwhelmed Evelyn Wang who's in tax trouble with IRS, divorce trouble with her long-suffering husband, and relationship trouble with her daughter. Yeoh deserves an Oscar for her exceptional performance as a woman who discovers her true powers.

Jamie Lee Curtis camps through the role of a frustrated IRS agent and might take home a trophy for best supporting actress. Stephanie Hsu manages not to mess up her dual roles as Evelyn's lesbian daughter and some sort of evil goddess called Juba. The male actors were all fine in their roles.

But for some reason, other than when Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis were on-screen, I found myself bored with the film's existential platitudes and truly wanted it to end. Okay, so I at least found the spinning bagel funny. (I won't explain.)

The Academy's Oscar "representation" requisites were fulfilled by having a mostly Asian cast, a female lead, a disabled father, and several gay-girl scenes. You might find it interesting to review the Academy's recent "representation guidelines," which in my opine are over the top. However, they do explain why you're now seeing so many gay-girl scenes in films.

The most disposable scenes were two rocks in the desert discussing the futility of their existence. Heck, cutting that scenario might have reduced the run time by at least 10 minutes. Truly: was this "Waiting for Godot" in rock form? I got the feeling those scenes were added in post by someone who thought using rocks was a brilliant idea.

Forgive me for being either too jaded or over-lit-majored or envious of the filmmaker's amazing ability to put this thing together and win an Oscar, but the Pat-Oh-Meter gives this highly rated, highly touted film only 3.5 out of five stars.

Call me old-fashioned, but originality in film should include creativity in what words emanate from the actors' mouths—and especially what emotions those words instill in the audience. A great film should not be an endless melange of bizarre, creative, and entertaining scenes.

I kept asking, "Is it over?" And when it finally was, I asked, "Was that it?"

I get both the good and the bad reviews for this movie. This movie is hard to understand and had a complex, almost ridiculous plot line. It uses things like the multiverse and martial arts to help tell the story, which I don't think it needed, but it was what the screenwriter and the director wanted to use, possibly to make this a unique premise, something never really tried before - though in different ways it has been done in other movies to different extents. The basic gist of the story is a mother who is trying to connect with her husband and her daughter, and how in all the different universes they find that connection, and where they lose also lose their connections to each other. It is also a very philosophical movie, touching upon the absurdity of life and our humanity. It takes awhile in the movie to get to that point. You have to deal with the odd and sometimes confusing plot points to reach it, but if you can get through all of that mess, there is a gem there. But not everyone will find it or maybe even understand it. I think the people making this movie wanted to be unique, and did so to a fault. I think it could have been toned down a bit, without all the odd extras. The essence of the story was pretty good, but the execution was somewhat off. But I do think if you can get to the end, and you can finally understand the true message, it will impart a good impression on you. I think the acting was very good overall. Now if you are one of the people that started the movie, but couldn't get through it the first time, skip forward about halfway, and rewatch it. I think you'll really start to understand it from that point on. I think the movie might start to make more sense to you.

Packed to the brim with big ideas, challenging cinematography, uproarious laughs, and surprising action Everything Everywhere All at Once is a genre-less thrill ride that proves itself as one of the year's best films. The movie begins simply enough: a Chinese immigrant family who owns a laundromat gets audited by the IRS for overextending the definition of the phrase "write-off." When they have to go speak with an IRS agent (played magnificently by the great Jamie Lee Curtis) the result is anything but simple. Evelyn Wang, the family's matriarch (played by the exceptional Michelle Yeoh) is approached by a different version of her husband, Waymond (Ke Huy Quan). This version is from an alternate reality and he warns that there is a multiversal force that threatens the existence of every reality and that this version of Evelyn Wang is the secret to defeating this ominous, evil force. This threat turns out to be a version of Evelyn's daughter, Joy (played by the scene-stealing Stephanie Hsu), who is capable of tapping into other versions of herself in order to borrow their skills to ensure that her abilities are limitless. What results is a surprisingly intimate look into family, potential, and self-worth against the backdrop of infinity. It's a film that defies any sort of pigeonhole; viewers will laugh throughout, be amazed at the choreography of the fight scenes, and will even cry when the total weight of everything starts to be addressed. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a movie who's title can be believed, it's a visual spectacle that is sure to stick with you well after the credits roll. It's a thematically rich tapestry that proves just how big a single film can really be, I can't wait to watch it again.

Everything Everywhere All at Once deserves all of its flowers. This was the wildest, most out-of-left-field, melt-your-brain-confusing, unabashedly silly and sincere movie I've seen in a while, maybe ever. The story was so creative, and as it got more and more complex, I became more and more invested. So many different avenues were explored, and so many weird ideas were brought to fruition and I loved it. There were a lot of little touches that I liked, too, not the least of which were the two little rocks and Randy Newman voicing a freaking raccoon. That man doesn't miss. Aside from those oddball moments, the movie's message (one that you had to cut back a lot of madness to see) was really great, and the performances were outstanding. Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan were phenomenal, but really no one slacked. My only qualm with the movie, and the reason that it's not getting 5 stars for now, is that I'm 100% positive I didn't fully understand everything, and now I'm going to have to find a YouTube video to break it all down for me. Once I watch that, though, I may come back and change my rating. What a fantastic movie.

But after rewatching it after some time, I am convinced that it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across. Granted, I haven't watched, read or played every movie/show/play, book or game ever created in the many languages that exist. But of the significant portion of my life I have spent experiencing stories and my subjective & biased parameters for what an exceptional form of storytelling should ideally be based on, I am certain that this movie is the best I've come across yet.

Why do I think that?

Because it combines the most investigated philosophical question of the purpose of life, the most complex metaphysical theory of multiverses and the most consistently prevalent emotions of hope & despair, all together, in 150 minutes that span almost every storytelling genre there is.

And it does this with a series of truly extraordinary & powerful acting performances, elegantly simple yet extremely compelling dialogues, absurdist yet coherent editing & transitions and one of the most narratively complementary cinematography ever.

Furthermore, the exceptionally intelligent use of various styles of humour, balanced with a metaphorical yet deeply compassionate use of relationships, to construct a narrative that - though may appear comically-absurd & entertaining on a casual first-watch - is actually so much more; being consistently deliberate, methodical & profound on a second viewing.

All this coalesces into a unique emotional journey - with an abundance of excellent humour - that inevitably transitions to a rollercoaster ride of hope crescendos & despair diminuendos, while offering convincing justifications for these ebbs and flows, concluding in an extremely cathartic & appropriate ending.

Everything Everywhere All at Once - as the title suggests - is truly a story about everything, everywhere, told all at once. It's the most conclusive story of existence. And as cliched and inaccurate its ultimate moral may seem, it ingeniously conveys it in the single most hopeful & captivating manner possible.

And that's why it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across.

This feels like a film that can't or shouldn't exist. It's like a lightning strike in that it can only happen in that exact way, and only once. It's monumental that it exists at all, or that it got green-lit, or that it was as big and sprawling as it was, or that it was able to go so many places within its runtime, or that it was giving the love, care, and budget to be all it could be. If even a single one of those factors was left out, this would not have been the film it needed to be.

It's hard to even describe this film. It's just so dense and packed with meaning. I think it was a little bit over-hyped at times, because the absolute insanity of the plot does drag it down a bit from the much more poignant core messages that the film wants to express.

But then again, this film wouldn't be itself without all that nonsense. It needs to be nonsensical and even farcical to make it's point. Nothing matters, but the key is, nothing has to matter to make you happy.

This film doesn't have to matter, and yet it does. This film doesn't have to matter, and yet so many people find joy and meaning out of it. It is its own self-fulfilling prophesy just by daring to exist. And that's pretty neat.

My own interpretation of the story, which makes far more sense to me than the whole Metaverse thing, is that our main character, Evelyn, has a psychotic break from all the stress she’s under, which causes her to revisit (while in a psychotic episode) all the fractured and splintered parts of her life, where she finds a way to repair them all—ultimately finding her true self at last. My own little fairy tale about the real nature of this story made enough sense for me to actually understand and enjoy it, at least from that perspective!!!

In the competition for the Oscar this year, the highest number of nominations was won by "Everything Everywhere All at Once", which I did not think deserved any review, but since there is really no reasonable achievement in the offer for the award, here are a few words about it, and some attempt at analysis everything that will possibly happen to us at the assignment.

The theme of parallel worlds is not new either in science fiction or in the film industry. The revived interest is due to the influence of the late-phase Marvel movies. So, if this film wins some awards, it will be a kind of victory for Marvel, since they didn't manage to push their "Wakanda Forever", which should not be at all in this year's competition. By the way, it should be said that the nomination of Angela Bassett for supporting role is controversial, because no matter how good the actress is, the film for which she receives the award should still be good, which is not the case here. And Chadwick Boseman was a good actor, but no one thought of nominating him for the highly overrated first part of the "Black Panther" series.

What to say about "Everything..."? The film is technically excellent, the camera and direction are outstanding, the inspiring ways of filming deserve all the praise. But that would be all about it. Short cut shots, jumps from universe to universe, kaleidoscopes of colors and a variety of scenography, all of which would make it seem as if something is actually happening, cannot be a substitute for an overly thin script (if there was one at all). Anyway, the awards follow him in any case, because the film is sufficiently "woke" and feministic, and the actresses Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis were up to the task. As someone has already noticed, Jamie Lee could be easily a tax collector in a parallel universe, if she hadn't been acting.

As for other accomplishments in the competition, there is little positive to say. "Triangle of Sadness" is a bad amateur film, it will be really sadness if it really wins an award. Spielberg definitely failed with "Fabelmans" (already nicknamed "Boremans" by the audience who watched it), the idea that three or four segments of the film be directed as different genres from the history of cinematography resulted in only boring cliches, without any sense, except perhaps for the author himself. "Babylon" is a total failure, and will be remembered only for the director's fascination with human (and animal) fluids. For a reason, it wasn't nominated for anything important, except for original music. But in that case, it would be better if they made a movie about a black jazz trumpet player (one of the secondary characters), if it is their original music, because the mindless repetition of "Singing in the rain", which they drowned out in the movie, was probably not the reason. "Banshees of Inisherin" with its extraordinary scenography and costumes, did not reach the level of even a third-rate film. The only Oscar, as far as can be seen, should go to the donkey, who, through no fault of his own, dies in the end, because he lasted so long to be in the movie. The other candidates hardly deserve to be mentioned, or I have already mentioned them in other places.

I would not talk about the films that were the only commercial success, such as "Top Gun: Maverick" and "Avatar 2", on this occasion. It seems that Hollywood is left only to reward achievements that are technically well done, good stories and interesting topics should be given up, because no one picture them anymore, nor does they take them into account. Sad days for cinema lovers.

(I think the positive reviews are likely the result of a bandwagon effect--you're supposed to like this movie, right?) It is full of Jackie Chan-esque fight sequences that don't hit the mark. The swelling music at the end where the daughter and mother have a heart-to-heart is so poorly done that it is sad but not in the way intended. It is interminable, too. This really was one of those films that sit with you for a few days and make you think about its premise in your own life. Such a thought-provoking and original story, with deep characters brought to life by the brilliant cast. Michelle Yeoh's performance showcased wonderful character development, alongside Ke Huy Quan's effortless ability to portray the many lives of Waymond. 

The visuals of the film are absolutely stunning. Some have described it as "an assault on the senses", which I certainly agree, though it is coherently done so that the audience is not feeling confused or left behind. Colours and slow-motion, among other special effects, are used to create sequences that may read as "ridiculous" on paper but are visually fantastic.

A masterpiece in writing, acting, and visuals - 10/10

Don't hate me. I really tried to watch this but couldn't get through it. I thought it was disjointed, non-linear ... and I felt old and out of touch because I didn't enjoy it.  I hope it doesn't win the Oscar for Best Picture because ... it's not the Best Picture this year.  Not even close.  Still, so many people just loved it.  To each their own.
While certainly entertaining, the point of the movie ended up eluding me.

Way more than what I expected.
Emotional, racional and crazy, just like life on this infinite universe.
I really like the story and characters style but can't get its words. I couldn't see the connection between parallel worlds and family problems.
as if pulp fiction and matrix had a child  I loved it, best in years I have seen
Long movie that made no sense at all. I don't get how it was nominated for 11 Oscar's.
the girl next to me was bawling, but my resolve was slightly stronger.

Honestly, I cannot believe this mess of a movie received 11 Oscar nominations. It is a boring, confusing jumble of a movie that is hard to sit through. The accolades this movie is getting greatly diminishes any credibility the Academy has left. As for the critics who have written raves for this garbage, go get another job. Please.

Both my husband and I found it hard to follow, it didn’t know if it was a comedy, action, sci-fi or drama. The editing made it tedious to watch, cutting back and forth. It could’ve ended many times before the actual ending. How it could generate 11 Oscar nominations is beyond me.

I really really don't understand why people like this movie it was by far one of the worst stories for a movie i've ever seen. Predicable, uninteresting and with one of the worst main characters i've seen in a long time.
