Stellar performances paired with the most creative yet simple story of the last decade makes this movie a must-watch for everyone. A wacky adventure with familial themes made this arguably the best movie of 2022.
This is one of the bravest, most original, and most entertaining movies I have ever seen.  It will be seen as a classic.

I really enjoyed Quan's performance.  I think Yeoh was a miscast.  Should have been Jackie Chan.  Otherwise, for me this was a mess of a movie.  It was difficult to follow.  The visuals literally gave me headaches.  The fatal flaw was the writing.  It was obviously directed by a 2nd or 3rd generation Asian American for non-Asians.  Made for those with identify crisis.  Just not my cup of tea, but I'm sure this will connect with millions of others.  When are we going to ever have an Asian American movie that is truly good?  No not this, not Crazy Rich Asian.
Incredible story with amazing visuals.

I cried through much of this movie as I found it so profound. The struggles expressed by Evelyn through the concept of multiverses as her internal world starts to collapse was just brilliant. If you are expecting simple entertainment, this is not it. You actually have to really show up for this one.
Just fantastic film-making and performances. The principal cast is uniformly excellent and takes this already well-written film to new levels of cinema. I absolutely loved it.

When a writer has apparently thrown every conceivable idea at a screenplay it's an incoherent mess. This film works so perfectly that by the time a small dog is being used as an assault weapon and inadvertently gets stuck in a fridge, even this dog-lover and his also dog-lover wife were howling with laughter and joy. What a deliriously inventive and fun film this is. 

But, of course, it's not only that - as if that wasn't enough. It's also got much to say about how we see ourselves, each other and our relationship - and manages to do so without feeling overly sentimental or heavy-handed. 

The performances are whole-hearted and spectacular, with inevitable special reference to Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis. The direction and writing are similarly superb; really there's not a department of this film that isn't working brilliantly, in sync with all the rest. It's a more warm-hearted, emotionally connected Inception; it's life-affirming and hopeful, whilst true to pain. We all need it in our lives.

Bloody gore,way too much violence, terrible sets (laundromat and hallway), no storyline, no creatvity or big ideas, loud, lousy, in short a stinker! I wrote better stories in high school. There is no 'everywhere' in this movie, although I couldn't watch more than the first half-hour or so which seemed like 3 hours! Don't believe anything positiive you read about it!! It rates in my top 10 worst movies with the Big Lamebowski, Life Aquatic and Pulp Fiction. For the life of me I can't figure out what anyone sees in any of these idiotic movies. I can't give it a negative score on here but I would if I could!!

Brilliant.  Best film of the year.  From writing, directing, acting, effects, etc, everything was on point.  The film represents an amazing alternate universe.  It was so very fun, funny, and emotional.  Loved it.
it was really one of the best movies i've watched all year, great acting, great plot, definitely going to watch again!
an amazing, fantastic adventure into our lives

I don't even have words to explain how amazing this was - never had a movie experience like this before. It was a wild wild ride, I laughed, was stunned, was amazed, was thrilled and I most definitely cried, but all sorts of tears were shed, happiness, exhilaration, sadness … it's just amazing. Best movie of the year. 

Excellent acting, filmmaking, film editing, writing, costumes, sound … just superb.
Movie is just plain corny.
Far too long . I fell asleep.
The first 20-30 minutes needed to pick up for me, once it did, I fully enjoyed and cried hard. It was beautiful, powerful, and fun as hell. Super impressive.

Great film. I think this movie share roots with "It's a Wonderful Life" and "Scrooged" which is timely, as I just watched this on the week leading up to Christmas. 

Super bizarre, over the top weird, delightfully self aware, I loved this film. I misses on being a top 5 star film for me, because it is so bizarre and without a 'plot' that I doubt I will watch it again anytime soon. But this watching experience is unlike any other I have had. I felt as though I was spoken to by the film directly in emotion. I loved that the rules were set, that being that there were none, and literally anything could happen and be acceptable as a viewer because, why can't it?

Great actors and characters, i really liked the Dad and the Daughter, the IRS auditor was super, especially with the hotdogs.

Highly recommend, but know you are not watching a 'normal' movie.
inexplicável inexplicável inexplicável

Hilarious, excellent scénario and a lot of action. This was a real good suprise for this end of the end of the year. One of the best film I have ever seen. 
The multiverse concept is very well exploited. The MCU should learn lessons here !
Wild movie. Well done acting, story, effects. Definitely out there and multiple times thought to myself “what are you watching right now”. But great meaning to the story and really well done.
very insane in the beginning. Takes a sharp turn into internalized childhood trauma town near the end. amazing enough for me to open this account and leave this review.
Amazing, hilarious, postmodern (in the best sense). Like nothing else.
Frantic, jarring, slightly convoluted and juggling many different things…Everything Everywhere All at Once is also equally as hilarious, creative and stylish.

The first thing I tell people about this film is that it's not science fiction and it has nothing to do with multiple universes.  If you accept that assertion then the true value of the story becomes evident.  For me this is a plot device used to cleverly tell a parable. That makes it unique and exceptional.
She should have just paid her taxes

You're either going to love this movie or hate it.  I'm firmly in the latter camp.  Excruciatingly dull, uninteresting story that left me utterly cold.  For the life of me cannot understand how this made so many 'years best' lists.  Was really looking forward to streaming it but couldn't make it past the 45 minute mark or so.
This was a great take on the parallel universe idea. It is quirky and funny, with a serious story under it all about family.
Indescribably wonderfully perfect at all it sets out to accomplish, which just so happens to be kinda everything.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a very charming and hilarious film. The movie concept is unique and I think Ke Huy Quan had an incredible performance as Waymond. The visuals are stunning and I loved the soundtrack. You can feel how much effort the cast and crew put into this movie and I think the product is something they should all be very proud of.
Best movie of 2022 no doubt

I dislike most movies that have been coming out in the last decade or so, this is such a good movie I got a Rotten Tomatoes account just to share how awesome I think it is. The trailers really caught my eye but I missed the first run of theater showings, so I first saw it in theaters upon its re-release, then almost immediately rented it to watch with a friend, and then bought it shortly after that so that I can re-watch my favorite scenes, only one other movie has ever impressed me even half this much. The performances are absolutely electric, it looks visually amazing, the music is fantastic, it's hilarious, it's emotionally moving, it's chaotic, absurd, and just a completely wild ride from start to finish. I have no doubt this is going to be a timeless cult classic for decades to come and I hope the love for this movie never dies.

This movie, if that's even a covering title for what is this masterpiece of visuals, sound, acting, plot, writing, I mean, it just kicks ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING thing else I've ever consumed, to the dust!! Every single one of my previous top 5, 10, 100, movies gotta drop at LEAST!! 20% in rating to even give room to just barely squize this inn on a simple mere 100, like, if possiple, I'd give it an everything bagel rating;)

PS!!: DO NOT, watch without subtitles yeah?, like damn me for spoiiling the first time watching with having them off, but at the same time I actually kinda got to watch it as new, a bit at least, for a second time, sooo I meeeaaan, do or don't, now you're at least informed as I wasn't.

The best movie made this year, the perfect combination of funny, disturbing, philosophical and sad- it never gets boring and has a unique approach to universal questions. Really makes you feel different about life.
Michelle Yeoh is a beast and I loved this film, Racacoonie!!

I know I'm in the minority here, but I just didn't care for this movie. Was excited to see it because of all the hype, but after seeing it didn't get the hype. I thought the acting performances were excellent, but the story line and the visuals just didn't do it for me.

A chaotic movie in the best way possible. The film never slows down and even better (or worse) always speeds up! Everything is in the mix between family drama, kung fu movie, sci-fi, absurd, contemplative moments all of that with colorful and sometimes very original visuals. The film plays like a maestro juggling with all these things, and it is helped by a very game cast.

It can be exhaustive for some, I understand it, sometimes I feel like the movie was about to end just to realize that I was only at the third of it, but as much exhaustive as it can get, you are absorbed by it and, at the end, it's rewarding. Beside all the craziness, the movie is, at his core, a family drama and a good one I must say, you will care about the characters even when they are in their most basic universe.
Constant non-sense brings nothing to the table.

My movie of 2023 and it is difficult to decide which I liked more between this and Topgun Maverick. Everything, Everywhere All At Once is a surreal family drama with highs, lows and everything in-between. Well acted, visually stunning and deserves world wide acclaim.
A great movie, a lot of layers, stunning visuals, a fresh breeze of creativity. i enjoyed it a lot. can recommend.

A mind numbing excercise. The title does say it all, it's a feast for your senses, and you'll need a good second viewing to even begin to figure it out what it all means. I just saw it for the first time, and at the end, I'm like, "oh, was that what this was about? OK". It's very good, but bloody exhausting. Fave actor in this was not Michelle Yeoh or Jamie Lee Curtis. I just loved Ke Huy Quan in this, such a masterful fun performance!
This film has everything, it's silly, funny, sad, ridiculous, poetic, philosophical, dramatic, violent, well acted, directed and shot. Hands down, Film of year.

What do the Multiverse, hotdog fingers and an everything bagel have in common? You wouldn't believe me if I told you. The great Michelle Yeoh shines in this film that will make you laugh, scratch your head, and probably cry, as you try to figure out what the Hell is going on. It's a mess, it's a train wreck, and I loved every single second of this ridiculous spectacle. In addition to Yeoh's incredible work, there is Oscar-worthy work from Ke Huy Quan, Jamie Lee Curtis and Stephane Hsu and I am not even going to try to explain this to you. Just see it. And half of you will absolutely hate it. But see it anyway.

Perhaps one of the greatest films I have ever seen. Definitely one of the most ambitious. It is not be for everyone - the movie travels and breakneck speeds and fans of more conventional blockbusters may leave the movie feeling confused. But for me, it automatically has its place in my Top 10 favourites. Well done to cast and crew.
An impressive film but drags a bit.
So fresh and original.  I hope it wins all the awards!
This was one of those experiences where I just cannot understand what other people found entertaining. Apparently bizarre visuals are supposed to justify a tedious, repetitive non-plot.
I loved it. Very original.
If you like pop culture references to everything everywhere all at once, then this is your movie.  A total homage to The Matrix and kung fu.  Especially kung fu.  Just.  Plain.  Boring.
I loved this movie.  It was so unique and well-done!  I loved the characters. It was not what I expected.  It was unbelievably good!  Well done!
Yeoh is a legend!  An entertaining mix of imagination and action with a human side.
If you don't have a sense of humor and an open mind, don't watch.

I can't believe the critical praise for this. I admit the concept is intriguing and I love 'multiverse' science fiction, but this was a confused mess that started its 'ending' about midway through the film. For the next hour I was waiting for the mayhem to die down so that something could happen with the plot. Nope. It just keeps going. I had to fast forward to the ending, which was dull in itself. 
The one shining moment is when the movie gets quiet, and a scene between the main characters (as rocks) in a 'dead universe' is animated entirely using subtitles on the screen. No audio. It was daring for a modern film, and it stands out in my memory as a truly original idea. The rest of it? Everybody was kung-fu fighting, and for what, I don't know or care.
The action and acting was good but it was so weird to the point that it just got way out of hand a couple of times I almost stopped watching.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It was the first movie in a long time where I found myself on the edge of my seat excited to see what would happen next. Hence the 4.5 star rating. I think that this movie can really start a trend of getting away from the traditional plot and theme that Hollywood has been giving to us and bringing back thrilling movies. I thought that this movie was a fantastic model of embracing the hecticness of the multiverse and creating beautifully crafted scenes that meshed so well together. I also thought the choice of cast was great. The only superstar actress being Michelle Yeoh, it goes back into us showing Hollywood that we don't need the same traditional actors to make a great movie.

I saw it four times in theaters and cried every single time. The movie has everything I want in a film and is endlessly entertaining. It just absolutely blew me away. It's exactly what I needed in a film exactly when I needed it. Thank you, Daniels.
a fantastic, highly emotional and sometimes cynical impression of nowaday's nihilism and the search for love. and you find it where it's least expected 😁
One of the best movies I've seen in a decade. Action, Emotion, comedy, the multi-verse. It hits all the topics I love most.
The best movie of 2022 hands down!
Absolutely incredible, I loved every second.

This is a bizarre, messy action movie. I kept expecting a switch in tone and tempo. 95% of the movie is the bizarre fighting and action, so do not stick with it if you aren't enjoying the chaos. I am stunned at the high ratings
its like the modern day over the top special effects adaptation of its a wonderful life

Maybe the best movie of the year. Certainly the best, most entertaining movie I saw this year. Original, crazy, funny, philosophical, moving, and bizarrely enough, as real as it gets. The time travel/dimension hopping obviously wasn't real, But the family dynamics and relationships felt universal. Your spouse gets on your nerves, your kids drive you crazy and vice versa, and yet you find the thread through all the drama to maintain your love for your family. That was the real part. 

The action sequences and the take on dimension hopping was crazy and fun. The most original take I've seen in scifi so far. I'd like to see a physicists take on it. Those may have been the funniest action sequences ever put into a movie. Jackie Chan meets gross out humour. Hilarious. 

And Ke Huy Quan did an amazing acting job. I didn't realize he was the kid in Indiana Jones: Temple of Doom. He got on my nerves in that movie. But here as a husband, father, and fight scene actor he was incredible. He switched personas, kicked butt, and was tender sometimes in the same scene.

Speaking of acting, this may be Michele Yeoh's finest acting job. She was great in Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, but here she plays a very flawed person coming to grips with her failures and successes. 

She and Quan were great together and the entire cast was a hoot. I totally did not recognize Jamie Lee Curtis until I saw her name in the credits. Stephanie Hsu deserves more work. Great movie. Well worth your time.
One of those movies that are worth rewatching which is really rare these days.

I appreciate this is different from anything I've ever seen.  (That said, isn't every non-documentary film it's own universe?)  Jamie Lee Curtis is awesome as is the rest of the cast. Stupendous choreography. Hilarious weaponry; hot dog fingers and plugs and more. One thing: was there no budget for costumes? Fun times! Way better than the Spidey multiverse: only three?

I can see this movie not being for everyone.

But i'd bet 75% of people would love this movie. I mean it basically could be considered part of almost every genre. 

If you dont mind your movies being silly, def give this a chance. Its my favorite of the last decade or so.

 it's got everything. everywhere....all at once.
one of the best of the year.
While the premise and plot was great, the low budget constraints made it more of a comedy than the writing.
Action packed. There’s not one dull moment in this film epic. It’s one of those films where if you rewatch for a second viewing, your bound to see something different.
A moving Chinese family drama crossed with The Matrix, Dr. Strange, Jackie Chan, Terry Gilliam and Charlie Kaufman. The kind of movie that only comes along once every twenty years.
simply amazing! great story, great acting, great movie

performances, character writing, characters, pacing, cinematography, story, editing, visual effects, representation, comedy, rewatchability, and tearjerking scenes. every single aspect of film perfected into this masterpiece of film thank you for making this movie

This is now my new favourite movie of all time. A merging of so many different but aligned elements. A family struggling to recognise their importance to one another. A mother bridging two worlds. A husband losing faith in love. A wife whose love registers barely a blip. And an inter-universal daughter hellbent on throwing herself into a void. I cannot express how perfect a movie this was for me. I was cut apart by the sadness. The existential dread becoming apathy. Depression delivered so expertly. And that love is not always about holding someone safely away from harm, but sometimes to jump into danger with them. To hold them close as we all fall together through the many tragedies we live through. And not being lost in what ifs, but in finding the joy in the fact it could only really be this way for us. Amazing. And delivered in a way that was deep but not without joyfulness. Serious but not without mirth. Amazing.

The cast is great, especially the leads, with a fresh perspective on (Spoiler Alert!) "The Matrix" motif and world within this fresh context. But this film broadens the emotional depths and literally plumbs the depths of the multiverse theme in a believable way such that this rollercoaster of a film fits together nicely and really takes flight to paraphrase the methodologies of writing in, say, an Ishiguro fantasy trope. But this instant Sci-fi Classic is very ambitious and has a lot to say within the context of an IRS office building / the time-space continuum. 
I would recommend this movie highly to anyone who appreciates the genre, likes "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and/Or "The Matrix." And likes a visual trapeze of a storyline which keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole way through! (Stay tuned for Part II…;)
Whacky, but yet beautiful film. Introduces a recent popular scientific theory and runs with it pushing the multiverse concept forward.

Innovative, provocative, absurdist, pretentious (yes) and overall incredible, it's probably one of the decade's best films. It's also a little too over-the-top to readily welcome repeat (or even single sitting) viewing. Regardless, you've gotta see it.
That's one hell of a movie. It's plot, cast, visuals everything is stunning.

This has to be the greatest movie of the year in my opinion. I would imagine that it will be the cause of inspiration for many movies from here on out. If I was to describe this movie simply, it portrays our crazy complex life in an over exaggerated way. The acting was phenomenal, being able to change personality's mid scene with such fluidity was beyond impressive. The consistent character growth among the many spectacularly crazy events unfolding throughout the movie allowed me as a viewer to understand what was going on while keeping me on the edge of my seat, demanding my attention, threatening to leave me behind if I so much as blink. The movies ability to increase tension, fear, and dominance through comedic tools such as Jobu Tupaki's plethora of ridiculous costumes and theatric kills. One can't help but feel the weight of her power and conviction. These are just a few things I loved about this movie but my words can't come close to describing how much I loved this movie.
Incredibly silly, heartwarming, and intelligent and all at once. Simply the most entertaining film I have watched in a long, long, long time.
Good film but it became less interesting as it progressed. Beginning was exhilarating, middle was action packed, the ending not so spectacular.

greatest film ever made, will surely win all awards in all areas. Simply incredible storytelling with amazing editing and superb acting. That said, I had to watch this film 4 times to fully understand all the themes and messages.
Movie of the year if not the decade.

"The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" is a modern sci-fi classic. It also inspired a glut of art-school string theorists. Their latest offering is "EEAAO" - a visually overstimulating, philosophically vapid attempt at an existential statement. I had hoped this brand of quirky nihilist humanism would die when Rick and Morty was cancelled. This film is like watching Neil DeGrasse Tyson's "Cosmos" on molly.
While the acting is uniformly excellent, and the action sequences are well directed, the weak screenwriting belies Daniels' apparent confidence in their art. The "grand statement" that subjective experience and emotion gives meaning to an objectively meaningless existence is  questionable, as this worldview has no greater philosophical power than the conventional worldviews that Daniels' spend two and a half hours gleefully undermining. This could've been an excellent family drama that engages maturely with the philosophical questions that Daniels' seem so keenly aware of. I guess they were too busy beating existential morality to death with a dildo to care.

I didn't go see this in theaters because I thought it looked really weird and waited to watch it online for .99.  I'm glad I did.  This is a really weird movie that flashes back and forth between all these verses and I found it really hard to follow.  On the other hand, the acting is pretty amazing.  I found that there were way too many fight scenes in the movie, although I get why.  Found myself waiting for it to be over.
One of the weirdest films I've ever seen, but this film has some real potential to inspire anyone who watches it.
Awful. Boring. Overrated.
Instant classic. A truly a once in a lifetime film.

The movie was hard to start but once you pass the hour mark it gets good, really good! I commend the directors for taking on a tough task to execute such a wild script. They delivered on everything — the film editing, special effects, action choreography acting, and casting. I’m glad to finally see a movie that is original and in a class of its own. Michelle yeoh kicked ass too! This isn’t for everyone and I’d say it’s for real die hard movie fans. The Haters won’t appreciate the work put into it. Bravo !
Don't get the hype. The film was trying way too hard and got so ridiculous so fast. I could easily enjoy something like this if it were done differently.

Pretty unique and entertaining film. I loved the acting and special effects. Funny and touching at the end.

this is one of those rare gems that just surprises you from out of nowhere.  much like the Matrix did when it snuck into theaters & word of mouth quickly spread about what a sleeper hit it was, this movie deserves to be among the greats on that list, for not only being phenomenal in all categories, but especially because of how new & different & unique it is.

Short Round's Redemption!

I have left reviews on countless films that I have called "quirky", "unique" and "ridiculous". There is no film that first those descriptions more than Everything Everywhere All At Once. While the film is hilariously shocking, it is also action-packed and incredibly heartwarming.

This film has one of the most beautifully crafted messages that I have ever seen in film. I honestly cried for most of the last 30 minutes. If you can embrace the absurdities (or at least look past them), you will find a marvelous story about inner peace.

Best Character: Waymond
Best Scene: The Fanny Pack Fight
Best Quote: "I will always, always want to be here with you." - Evelyn
Best Piece of Score: "In Another Life"
It's an awesome movie
It's the most moronic movie I've ever seen & I've seen thousands of movies! Why in the world would Michelle Yeoh ever do this movie? Was she helping out a relative or friend?
Stylish.  So what?  Exhausting to sit thru.  Waste of talent on all fronts.  You just want it to be over.

This was a wonderful movie! It's hilarious and whimsical with notes of deep meaning hidden underneath. I could watch this movie more than once and that is not typically a thing for me. There is so much to glean from this movie! 10/10 would recommend to everyone I know!
The weirdest movie I've ever seen yet it had a relatable message. It was surprising and entertaining.
Simply amazing, imaginative, meaningful, creative, poetic, wacky, layered, moving, crazy, silly, and yet very GROUNDED and relatable.

What ultimately ends up being so impressive about Everything Everywhere All At Once is how simple its story really is, but how wildly complex of a route it takes to tell it. It's a story about generational trauma, grass is always greener thinking, and self acceptance, but what we see is kung fu, high kingdoms worshipping a bagel, rocks in a desert talking to each other, and Jamie Lee Curtis stapling paper to her forehead. It's incredibly inventive film making that is at times so inventive that it is difficult to keep up with. I, let alone anyone, is wholly unfamiliar with movies like this because they just don't exist. On top of being innovative, EEAAO is funny, smart, and feels like a grand adventure of epic scale with its grandiose visuals and  sweeping musical score. I don't think I could praise an edit of a movie more than this one. That said, it's middle third is tough to for me to remain wholly invested in due to its sheer absurdity. Some people will love that, some will bounce off it a bit. Either way, I really liked this and respect the hell out of it.
I gave it half a star for the originality of the concept.  Other than that, it ranks as one of the worst movies I've seen.

I thought this movie was so well done I actually created an account here to write this review. Incredible, didn't know what was happening or where it was going for much of the movie, but by the end I was in awe from what I had witnessed. One of the best movies I've seen in a long time

A universe where everyone has hot dog fingers? A raccoon chef brought about by a mis-pronunciation of ratatouille? A race to sit on a butt plug as a teleportation device? Rick & Morty has nothing on this masterpiece. Insane from start to finish

Absolutely a must watch, in my opinion a complete cinematic masterpiece. The action, comedy, sci-fi all of it was absolutely amazing. the metaphorical meaning behind it all (which can be many many things) just absolutely gorgeous. i loved it.

This movie is pure art.  Michelle Yeoh is simply brilliant and as far as I'm concerned she should win a Best Actress Oscar for her performance.  You will be in awe, you will laugh and in the end you might even shed a tear or two.  The action is also top notch.  In a world you think you've seen it all, this completely off the rails gem comes along and lets you know there is still some originality still left in the world.  Michelle Yeoh, the writers, director and the rest of the cast have much to be proud of here.
One of the dumbest movies I've watched in a long time.

One of the strangest movies to start but the 3 part act of everything everywhere all at once is one of the most genuine, original, and heartfelt movies of the year, possibly ever. Supporting cast is brilliant but no one can outshine Michelle Yeoh and the powerhouse she is.

It was a bit out there.  I was tolerating it to some level, however a scene come along where the evil foe uses a dog as a weapon - it's pretty bad.   This was an attempt to be comedic, but it was pretty dumb and no reason to have this type of animal violence in a movie.  Strong writing would not have to stoop to that level and therefore I turned it off after this scene.
Loved it. I was thinking about this movie for a week. Really made me think how much i love my family and made me care about them more that before.

An amazing multiversal story; as a sci-fi fan, it is rare to get such a mind melding premise mixed with such an emotionally resonant plot. For weeks after watching, I still couldn't get a certain timeline- noir-esque, blurry, rainy- out of my head. 
Laundry doesn't sound so bad.

Everything Everywhere All At Once is completely unlike anything else in cinema, yet is exactly like the 21st Century world outside of cinema. Disney has come to dominate the art form by giving us escapism, but this film is the real world as it is right now shown to us in a completely new and utterly compelling way. If that is not the very definition of artistic excellence, then I don't know what else counts.
fresh directing, great actors, and more than anything else, stories that remain in my heart for a long time.

Wildly imaginative and mindblowing, this film goes for Everything Everywhere All At Once with an artful approach that is upheld by its powerfully elaborate storyline, thematic depth and a masterclass performance by Michelle Yeoh.
The film in a nutshell: strange, deep, and well executed.

I have never in my life seen such a beautiful and perfect and utterly hilarious combination! After seeing this film five times, I cannot pick out flaws. For its budget and scope, it has absolutely shone higher than any blockbuster of this age. The plot is a deeply moving tale of family trauma, breaking cycles, acceptance, and it contains one of the most wholesome and perfect depictions of masculinity I've ever seen in an action film. An absolute must see, and a fresh take on film in general!

Everything Everywhere all at Once is a must-see film. If you are a fan of Sci-Fi and Action and an emotional roller-coaster, this film is for you. The acting is amazing, but the CGI or VFX done by nonprofessionals makes the whole film so much better than regular MCU films. Despite the tense action scene, Everything Everywhere all at Once doesn't fail to have comedy which will seriously make you laugh, and emotional scenes that you make cry. Great writing, story, action scene, color, visually stunning. Despite it having quite a bad ending, I enjoy and loved the film. Watch Everything Everywhere all at Once if you haven't.

Absolute masterpiece. I've never seen anything like this before. A very strange one tho, but if you allow it, the movie will take you to another universe (or more) to entertain, teach, touch your soul and laugh with you.

Fun, imaginative, creative, well-written, wonderfully performed. Not what I was expecting, even though I knew it was intended to be not what I was expecting. Contains interesting takes on the meaning of a life well-lived
I understood the movie and the subtle messages it got across but that doesn't mean I enjoyed it. Very creative but not my cup of tea at all.
A wild ride from start to finish. This is what Doctor Strange MOM should have been.
Beautiful and interesting story, loved every second of it.

Absolutely amazing, stunning and unforgettable. Easily in my top 5 movies.

A bizarre film, certainly not for everyone, however, it is a memorable and unique experience that you cannot get from anywhere. And in the core of its story lie some interesting ideas and a strange story that can be gripping although sometimes the weirdness can be overwhelming.
One of the best movies I've ever seen, made my top 10 immediately. Definitely must see!

Everything. Everywhere. All at Once.

This movie is the everything bagel of cinema.

If you want to see a movie about time/universe jumping watch the Matrix.
if you like movies with  Kung fu watch Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon.
if you want a satorical comedy and raunch watch American Pie or 40 yr Old Virgin.
if you want heart felt family drama watch A Beautiful Mind.
if you want an Asian mother daughter relationship movie watch The Joy luck Club.
i could go on but the gist is that pretty much any element that people find enjoyable in this movie has been done before and better in another movie. I think the people who like this movie simply haven't seen enough movies and TV shows. 

Honestly the plot wasn't hard to follow and its not hard to understand. It is just a basic sci fi multiverse plot with a family relationship thrown into the mix. Its not super deep. 

The acting was ok and so was the special effects/choreography. however the character development was extremely lacking. it was hard to root for a winner when you cant connect with the characters in a meaningful way. which was ironic in a movie that is basically all about how we are  all seeking connection and love. 

as for humor,.. well sure a good ol' shock value sex toy scene or politically incorrect animal abuse type of thing can elicit a reaction but only once. After that it just gets awkward and dumb. Kinda like the fight scenes after awhile they all blend into one another and its gets tedious. 

honestly this movie was one big hodgepodge of Asian stereotypes, sci fi, drama, feel good drama, slap stick, crude humor, LGBT, and artsy philosophical stuff. An LSD/ADHD nightmare that got thrown into a computer that used random code to spit out a movie that the masses would instantly deem a cult classic.

big fail for me.

Outstanding zany experience. It is probably too unconventional for traditional awards (beyond some visuals, which are also top notch). The gist of the show is something approaching a drug induced spiral into anxiety around paying your failing business' taxes, while trying to talk some sense into your daughter after losing your confidence and voice. 

I am not sure one needs a precise understanding of the magic at work to make someone everywhere and everything all at once. What you do understand though is the heart of the movie. It never leaves behind, I suspect in no small part because of the excellent performances of the leads, that core anxiety of ordinary problems. It is like watching a tight reconstruction of your best morning shower superhero fantasy. It's cute, has gusto and is a great ride. Worth a watch to experience it yourself.

A true rollercoaster ride. This movie is visually unique and action-packed with a family drama at the core. Your laughs will be loud, your attention will be captured, and your tears will be abundant. I absolutely love this film even with its quirks. Recommended to anyone interested in something outside the rehashed Hollywood blockbuster formula.
Best movie i have seen in a very long while!! it wasn't afraid to go outside the box... elements of comedy, adventure, meaning all in a movie. A very well done movie good job!
The title can turn your expectations high and at the end, it totally surpasses any of them with powerful and unforgettable scenes that make up a beautiful yet common family story.

As a Gen Z myself with an immigrant parent, I feel I relate to this movie a lot, especially dealing with criticism and depression. This movie gave me so much optimism and honestly made me so happy. It also opened my mind to thing about many other perspectives that could be involved in everything, how everything in the future is influenced by the smallest change. This movie made me cry 4 times, not of sadness, but of joy. I'm so glad this movie became a thing. Thank you so much.
Weird and absurd but fun, that is this movie right here folks.

An aptly named feature film, 'Everything...' found an emotional cadence in between all the universe-hopping violence.  The film most certainly makes you think and it is quirkily funny and richly layered.  It is a rare film of the time which may deserve a second viewing to take it all in.  It is, at its worst, a tad bit over-indulgent.  All the worlds aren't made to be understood, but they begin to make sense as a whole as the film continues on.  Everyone is great in this.  This worked for me, but it was a touch repetitive.  Final Score: 7.7/10

Just a phenomenal film, Visually spectacular,  goofy and funny but still cinematic,  fast paced and actioned packed , but then with all the emotion and thoughtful complexity you would find in the most intelligent drama. An incredie piece of film making.

A complex story that is not tedious or difficult to understand and that makes you reflect on life itself (although at times it felt pretentious by wanting to make the plot complex). Completely recommended.

I went to see this movie because of the rave reviews it got. I found it interesting and fun at first but it dragged on and on losing much of its entertainment value for me. I thought Michelle Yeoh was great and some of the fight scenes were very entertaining, funny in fact, but it just went on too long and I found it a bit disappointing considering the universally good reviews I saw. My wife fell asleep half way through while watching it in the cinema. I would, however, rewatch this movie to see what weird things I missed on the first watch.

A crazy movie with an emotionally plot, that's how I would describe this film. Even if it is a sci-fi movie, the sentimental part of the movie makes you think about things you don't even want to think. The movie takes place in some part of California, but also in other dimensions that take you to China, the desert or places that don't even exist in real life. What makes this film amazing are the special effects, the kung fu fights, makeup but above all, the costumes. I cried a lot with the end, it was something I wasn't expected.
This is the second-best movie I have seen on Love. "Eternal Sunshine of Spotless mind" still holds the torch.
This has to be one of the most imaginative, hilarious, emotional and down right genius films to ever be put on screen. It will go down as one of the greats.

Serious disappointment.  Considering the cast drawn together for this film, It had such potential, especially considering the concept behind the story.  It takes a grand concept and falls victim to the challenge of trying to do everything everywhere all at once.  If you're familiar with the movie "Up", just imagine "squirrel" distractions 96% throughout the film.  There is an element in the movie the characters seek to avoid (unless you've been drawn in and then they are driven towards it:  a bagel – yes a bagel.  Mushrooms would have served better because consuming bagels before making a movie never ended so badly. The story -- the core of it -- could have been relayed in about 12 minutes.  The rest was belabored.  The acting was notable, especially by Quan.  Hsu and Yeoh have the standout moments as well where they either are on mark or draw you in to the story, but this movie is ridden with so much that weighs it down -- who knew fluff could be so heavy??  Do yourself a favor and go buy a bagel instead – don't get sucked in.  Either that or eat some mushrooms (not recommended) and make your own movie… it can't be any worse.
The best multiverse film, the best film of 2022. MASTERPIECE.

An incredible movie that contains a not so subtle analogy for depression and the bittersweet love with one's family. I'm not sure I've ever seen anything like it. I'm not sure I ever will again. It made me laugh while crying, it made my heart race through as though the action were serious while being ridiculous. It satisfied on a level my ADHD mind found unbelievably comforting.

This movie has an amazing story, funny humor, and a great message. It is an amazing movie for anyone to watch and puts Multiverse of Madness to shame. If you have the time and money, what in the world are you doing reading this thing and buy the bloody movie already!

Like the many multiverse versions of us out there, this movie will have many different meanings to those who watch. That emotional connection Everything Everywhere All at Once, will hit you when you least expect it but at the exact right moment. It’s just different for everyone. That moment for me, well I can’t tell you that, but it was meaningful for almost no reason. Just everything about this movie is bizarre and perfect all at once. I’m one where the “great” movies grow on me in time and I feel this is definitely going to be one of those game changing movies. There’s just too much to unpack in one viewing and it’s very easy to just take at face value, which you need to adsorb the message and let it fester to really understand it. OR I can watch it again and be like wow this is just a very long drawn out old vine (remember them lol) video. For now, it’s the first thought and I’ll stick with that until I’m swayed in another direction.

More than lives up to its title. It's funny and sad and visually stunning. But, most impressively, it manages to be all of the following and somehow more: a love story between mother and daughter, two generations viscerally separated from one another by countless social and cultural sea changes; a howlingly funny comedy of errors; a redemptive romance; a showcase for every one of its inimitable, glorious stars; a chronicle of depression and the often-consuming pull of figurative or literal self-annihilation; and a celebration of the messiness of seeking meaning that ultimately functions as an extra-absurdist cinematic update to "The Myth of Sisyphus" as it explores the simultaneous futility and utter necessity of seeking meaning in a life that is often cruel and/or cruelly boring and/or overwhelming.
I must have been the wrong audience for this
I get that there's a message in there somewhere but this was an acid trip of a movie. The words to describe it are WTF? but not in a good way. It had stunning visuals and amazing editing though.
Not for everyone, but give it a chance. This is one of the best movies I have ever seen in my life.

Innovative, funny, and profound, "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" dares to capture and embrace the messy and uncertain reality that we live in. It is a beautiful commentary on the bridge between gaps in translation, be they linguistic, cultural, national, generational, racial, or due to sexuality or class.

Everything Everywhere All At Once truly can only be described as the best film experience most people will have all year and is a brilliant showcase for maximalist filmmaking and the unbridled power of cinema.
Michelle Yeoh proves she is still at the top of her game with this epic tale that explores the concept of the multiverse while at heart is a heart warming family drama.

Movie's biggest fail: Grotesque normalization of family abuse. 
Warning: animal abuse presented as humor.  (Played for laughs) where the small dog on a leash is swung across the room, first being thrown into a refrigerator, then again being swung around by the neck and thrown across the room, slamming into a wall divider and crying. 
The worst part of this though, was it was clearly written by two men who have zero understanding of the severe consequences of mother-to-daughter emotional battery.  Script seems to have been written to appeal to the same Boomers who said millenials were lazy and poor because 'they ate too much avocado toast'.  Skip forward a decade, replace 'avocado toast' with 'everything bagel' and now it's Gen Z who are selfish, lazy, self-centered, cruel, while 'poor hardworking ma' tried so hard despite her vicious, ungrateful loser of a kid bla bla bla.  

Notably, the mom never apologizes or makes any kind of amends for the damage she did and continues to do to her daughter, but apparently imagines her daughter as a sad, tacky, angry dump in attention-grabbing outfits, and the mom openly resents giving birth to her. 
The scene where she comes at her daughter with a box-cutter razor, also punches her daughter in the face, and the daughter lies and tells her dad she fell on the sofa was the end for me.  I kept watching, hoping this was the run-up to some drastic turnaround and self-realization at the end... but no.  
Both the mom character and the writers seem to have no clue as to why abuse victims leave their abusers. Being male writers, they understood why the abused *husband* filed for divorce papers, but couldn't quite grasp why the abused daughter would also deserve to leave. The rock scene was a great example of how much they failed to 'get it'. Could have been poignant if it weren't for the fact the mom couldn't do basic, fundamental things to make her daughter feel safe, like supporting her against her abusive grandfather, supporting her choice to date another woman, or at least at the bare minimum, stop calling her fat and destroying her self-esteem.  But we're supposed to believe the mom would jump off a cliff to follow her daughter LOL.  The sappy ending where the daughter shrugs off all of this lifetime of abuse and parental rejection as 'just me being dramatic... awkward' was pathetic and the upsetting downer of the whole film.  Never saw the abused dad figure saying, 'gee, let's call off the divorce and be a happy family again, this divorce stuff was just me being too dramatic'.  No. This if anything underlined the worst part of the film, the stereotypical expectation that women, especially, girls, are supposed to accept abuse and forgive their abusers and 'let it go'.

Positives: I liked seeing diverse Asian representation in film. Good special effects. 

Would I recommend it: NO.  This movie tried to appear 'deep' but was ultimately shallow and stupid, repeating harmful and degrading stereotypes. Visuals are creative but even those veer into the grotesque too often, like the naked man jumping on a butt plug. The normalization of family abuse and animal abuse was absolutely the most grotesque and unforgivable things about this film and I am sorry I spent $5 renting it.  Instead of watching this drivel, I'd suggest Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.  At least in ESotSM the characters do spend some time reflecting on how their behavior has negatively affected others and why others would choose to leave them.

"Everything, Everywhere, All At Once" is an aberrated, utter treat. From extraordinary acting to sharp visuals and sounds, this film shattered the laws of usual filmmaking, creating a mural of heartfelt symmetry. Michelle Yeoh playing Evelyn Wang, a laundromat owner who embarks on a confusing journey, is absolutely incredible and the cast countering her are limitlessly talented. Seemingly unhindered by the walls of our dimension, this film is everything we ever wanted.

This is a pretty frantic, colourful, somewhat madcap film, with some scenes featuring almost Matrix style choreography and the plot and pacing making me think of something like a constant neon coloured pinball machine, with the ball pinging about from one corner to the next. I liked that its set in such a domestic, dare I say particularly boring setting as an IRS office. The visual effects are great - I liked the cartoon strip feel to some effects in particular (I won't elaborate so as not to provide potential spoilers). 

I found it difficult to follow all the plot details but I certainly wouldn't say that affected my enjoyment of the film overall. Watching the fast paced fight scenes reminded me a little of kung fu or samurai films of the 1970s. At times Chinese songs are played in the background and it was nice to see the various family members speaking in their (I assume) mother tongue. As over the top as it undoubtedly is for the most part, there is a point in which things slow down significantly - that is somewhat poignant. I should perhaps note that a fair amount of the dialogue is in either Mandarin or Cantonese, hence subtitles are often present, which may or may not put you off it. Its a very engrossing and yet also somewhat baffling film, with a quirky, arty feel to it to an extent but enough mainstream CGI to entertain the audience well, I reckon. It's definitely a film to re-watch, as I was left thinking 'what did I just see?' by the end.

Needless to say, I would definitely recommend this film, yes.
Absolutely fantastic film. Touches just about every single emotion as it grows increasingly absurd and also intensely personal.
The best, most original, and most enjoyable film I've seen in a good long while.

There is a ton of stuff happening on many different levels - sometimes so overwhelming that it sets your head spinning - ideas about the multiverse, incredible martial arts scenes and a good amount of butt jokes. This movie has so much, it left me breathless. They will be talking about Everything Everywhere All at Once as a classic in the same league as Citizen Kane.

SPOILERS AHEAD - I read a few reviews about this movie before renting it, and was hooked when one of them said something along the lines of, "Like nothing you've ever seen." Um, yeah. As my mama would've said, this movie FLOORED ME. Another reviewer stated quite aptly I think that it's a philosophical argument between existential despair & Buddhist acceptance.

This movie is STILL making me laugh...I just looked the main character's husband's name up to make sure I remembered it correctly before typing it - I thought I remembered it being Raymond the whole time, and it's "Waymond." I think that's the point - hahahaha - pet rock - after you watch it, you'll get that:) This movie takes itself so VERY seriously, and then turns around and makes fun of itself and life. And it does it again and again and again, much to the delight of the unassuming viewer. About the pet rocks y'all, I thought I was gonna pee myself I was laughing so hard at that plane of existence. I guess they weren't technically pet rocks, but that is exactly how I saw them:) I was born in 1968, and some of you may not believe this, but we had pet rocks back in the 70s. Again, hahahahaha!!!! Humans - we crack me up.

I bawled like a baby when "Waymond" stopped one of the battles, begging everyone to just be kind. I think that scene captures so beautifully and sadly how we're all so stressed, tired and scared of living in the times we're living in. We are falling apart and have become quite combative from the stress, lack of sleep, lack of human connection, and any number of other traumas. There is more than one way to be a warrior...

OMG!!! when the mom/daughter story becomes clear, it reveals the catalyst for the whole movie IMO. She's reaching out for her mom across every plane of existence to try to be heard, which I think hits on the despair and angst of our youth - that broke my heart to pieces. For me, this movie really reinforces that we need to let our kids know we love them no matter what, even when they are acting evil and trying to drag us into their bagel hole;) It also points out how hard it is to not parent like your parents parented.

Jamie Lee Curtis as a milk-guzzling IRS agent with her damn wig and tight-ass sweater was fucking hilarious. The alternate plane her and Michelle Yeoh inhabit was nothing less than bizarre. Mmmm, hot dogs with mustard. This movie is an assault on the senses in the most enjoyable way you can imagine. Like a roller coaster ride! Thank you for making this movie:) It truly is one of a kind, and I hope it wins LOTS of awards. Joy to the World - hahahaha. Really though.

Yeoh, Man! -  Film Review: Everything Everywhere All At Once ★★★★1/2

Have you ever felt that the films of Baz Luhrmann and Michael Bay dragged a little? Do you need more edits? Faster action? More kablooey and kablam? Well, to paraphrase SNL's Stefan, "America's hottest movie, Everything Everywhere All At Once has everything! Talking  Rocks! Hot dog fingers! Backwards whooshing office chairs! A Sharpie wielding Halloween star!" Who knew, however, that it would live up to that hype and more, easily becoming one of the best films of 2022? 

The Daniels, Dan Kwan and Daniel Schienert, who last brought us the delightfully fantastical Swiss Army Man, return with an explosive (although with no farts this time) yet beautifully character-driven film which is literally about, as the title implies, EVERYTHING. Michelle Yeoh plays Evelyn Wang, a downtrodden laundromat owner who lives a financially desperate, hard-working life with her husband Waymond (the triumphant return of Ke Huy Kwan best known for his roles in Indiana Jones And The Temple Of Doom and Goonies), daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu of The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel) and Grandpa Gong Gong (James Hong). 

When we meet Evelyn, she's exhausted from her work load, strained in her marriage, and dreading an upcoming meeting with the IRS. Enter Jamie Lee Curtis, in an unforgettable performance, as Deirdre Beaubeirdra, a joyless tax auditor who has never met a part of her body she hasn't scratched. She has it out for the Wangs, issuing an ultimatum to get their receipts together or face the consequences. With all of the pressure reaching a boiling point and seemingly no way out, a surprise twist throws Evelyn and her family into one insane adventure after another, fracturing timelines, universes, and offering up a "Sliding Doors on Acid" premise guaranteed to make the most kinetic of directors green with envy. It gets very complicated with its kitchen sink approach, with some interludes feeling random or interchangeable, but I found it worth the ticket price alone for the image of Curtis flying in slow motion through the air to face off against Yeoh in just one of many heartstopping moments. Special mention must go to Larkin Seiple for his phenomenal cinematography, Shirley Kurata for ten films worth of insightful, memorable costume design, and Jason Kisvarday's production design, which features an impressive, memorable array of styles. 

Through it all, Yeoh navigates the impossible, playing a huge swath of characters, explosively executing complicated action sequences, and making us feel something deeply for our central heroine. She's giving the performance of her career here, able to capture our hearts while concurrently displaying the entire gamut of brittle neuroses in her wheelhouse. She plays so many different characters, some seemingly autobiographical, all of whom have a level of confidence and empowerment lacking in Evelyn herself. 

When Waymond steps in to motivate her, the movie really takes off with a series of brilliantly executed action sequences. Kwan, whose voice seems to have not aged a day, keeps up with Yeoh, delivering a heartfelt, fun, fast and furious performance all while doing flips and kicks guaranteed to earn him Instant Hunk status. It's so wonderful to have him back after years of giving up on acting. Here's to many more films to come. 

Also of note is Hsu, who starts off as the detached daughter who her family for not fully supporting her queerness. She, like the rest of her relatives, finds her own special superpowers, elevating her to icon status before the film ends. Who wouldn't want this badass to kick down a few doors for them? I was also very touched by the mother-daughter relationship depicted here. It succinctly gives so many young queer people the tools and language for having tough conversations with their parents. Kudos to this slam bang film for having educational purpose too, filled as it is with nuance and grace far beyond what one expects from a genre film.

If this movie wasn' so overhyped and so overrated, I would just dismiss it as a meh kind of movie. But as it is so overhyped and overrated, I kind of start to hate it.

But to not waste a lot more time on this nonsense, I will just point out the main reasons why the movie failed for me.

1.) The movie failed to establish an emotional connection between the viewer and what is happening on the screen i. E. in the movie. One of the reasons for that being: the movie was driven by nonsense. Whenever the main characters are stuck in a situation, the have to perform some nonensical bullcrap, so that they can crazy-deus-ex-machina their way out of the situation. Again and again and again and again and again.

2.) The other reason for the failed emotional connection is that there were no sympathetic characters given to connect with. Everyone is just a self-absorbed a-hole or douchebag. What they are fighting for is a chaotic piled up mess (because they are unable to fix anything and to improve, so they prefer having a meanignless mess to having nothing).

So, my main problem was: I just didn't care for anything happening in the movie.

If you think that it is a profound philosophical question to ask how your life would be if you would have sausages for fingers (just to give you an example), this may be a movie you. But if you think that such a question is just stupid and stopped being funny since you turned 8 years old, maybe you should avoid spending timeor money on this movie.

But there are some few reddeming qualities of this movie, hence I did give it 3/10.

Which are:

- The cinematography isn't bad.
- It doesn't look like a trash movie production-value-wise.
- Some of the acting wasn't too bad, if you can look past the garbage mess the actors had to work with.
- It has some funny moments, if you can take the nonsense and the stupidity.
- But again, at the end of the day, I didn't care for the pile of nonsense that the movie is.

Easily one of the most visually striking and conceptually original films of the 21st century, Everything Everywhere All At Once may have a cumbersome title, and an occasionally confusing to the point of tedium storyline, but its chock full of incredible ingenuity and genuine emotional weight. Michelle Yeoh, who in the last few years is finally getting the recognition she deserves, plays a downtrodden laundromat owner who is introduced to the secrets of the multiverse. The film has a similar problem to Inception and Tenet, in that the story is so complicated that lengthy scenes of exposition are required, and even those can make it feel more difficult to comprehend. But as the story progress you do develop something of a handle on things, and when you grasp the core concepts the film really comes into its own. I loved the way it handled themes of nihilism, family acceptance and the importance of understanding a person despite their differences, and while the middle section of the film can feel long and directionless at times, as it enters the 3rd act the film delivers some serious emotional gut punches, and everything that we've seen falls into place. The actors do a great job, the script is funny, insightful and cleverly constructed, and the lessons we learn come about completely organically. It's a film that many will find hard to digest, but if the cinematic medium is going to continue to evolve, we need films that are going to push boundaries and break new ground, and that's what this one does. If you can embrace its wackiness and accept its unconventionality, then you're in for a real treat.

Okay, so I am 74 so that probably influences my bad rating of this film to some extent. That being said, I am an author of numerous books and have written screenplays and appeared in a movie myself for what that is worth. Now to the film... I enjoy a good SF movie but this one made so little sense that I quickly found myself struggling to understand what I was seeing. The acting was okay but whoever edited the film created something that for me at least, was incredibly uninteresting. The character development was nearly non-existent. I found myself not caring a bit what happened to anyone in the film because everyone was frankly lacking in any redeeming qualities whatsoever.  It reminded me of a similarly distasteful film called MOTHER with Jenifer Lawrence. It is astonishing to me why talented, well-known actors would agree to appear in such a bad film. But even more astonishing is what great ratings the critics are giving it.  Makes me feel like a stranger in a strange land. No, I would NOT recommend anyone waste their time watching this film. What little message it contains regarding mother-daughter relationship struggles is entirely lost in all the chaos and stunningly schizophrenic behaviors of all the characters.

It seems most people love the out and out weirdness and randomness. That's fine, but it wasn't really my thing. It's still worth a trip to the theatre though. I'll have to give it another watch to really let it sink in.

The film title for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is its best possible plot summary.  The film is chaotic, disorienting, innovative, thought-provoking, undisciplined and profoundly moving.  It's impossible to summarize briefly.  But "Everything …" is also the best reason to venture out to a movie theater since the pandemic began over two years ago.

Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert – the Daniels - who co-wrote and co-directed this film, are veterans of several movie shorts and music videos.  Their previous feature film, 2016's "Swiss Army Man," is summarized by IMDb as follows:  "A hopeless man stranded on a desert island befriends a dead body, and together they go on a surreal journey to get home."  In "Everything …" they graduate from mundane topics like human mortality to tackle the multiverse.

The idea of the multiverse posits that there are an infinite number of universes – "alternate universes" or "parallel universes" – where the consequences of all the choices we make or don't make are played out to their logical conclusions.  It's an idea that has been endorsed by Stephen Hawking and Neil deGrasse Tyson.  But philosophically, it's a pretty depressing brand of nihilism: how can life have meaning if none of our choices really matter?

The Daniels use the multiverse for two purposes.  First, when characters jump from one alternate universe to another, the moviegoer can explore the alternate life stories of the primary characters, particularly Evelyn (a spectacular Michelle Yeoh - 2000's "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon") who is an unhappily married, dissatisfied co-owner of a laundromat whose main achievement has been disappointing her father.  But in alternate universes where she has made different choices, Evelyn is, variously, a famous singer, a star of martial arts films, a sign-twirler on the street, a resident of a universe where everyone has hotdogs instead of fingers and, most poignantly, one of two sentient rocks on an uninhabitable planet (the most touching scenes in the film).  Evelyn bounces from one universe to another to help her struggling daughter Joy (yes, I do see the irony) who, as many parents would predict, is both a confused young adult and also Jobu Tupaki, an arch-villain bent on destroying the multiverse.  In one scene, Joy/Jobu confides that she has used her superpowers to place all the important things in the world in a bagel (you got it:  an "everything bagel").

The Daniels also use alternate universes to explore core concepts around family dynamics: the paralytic effect of parental disapproval; the notion that a family member's quiet inaction sometimes represents kindness and strength, not passivity; and finally the strong suggestion that parental love is the most powerful force in the universe.
  
At the end of the day, this weirdly wonderful film shares a powerful theme with the Bible, the Torah, the Koran and almost any good Kurt Vonnegut novel: in a confusing, scary, sometimes brutal universe, we'd all be better off if we all treated one another with a little more kindness.

The cast of this movie expertly executed on each of their characters. The makeup, set, and costume design were impeccable and overall it was visually satisfying to watch. However…

I can't possibly be the only one that recognized the horrific and offensive display of misogyny in this movie. The mother/daughter relationship (and really the whole movie) was riddled with "hysterical woman" moments, ending with 30 minutes of cliche Pixar movie lessons that never seemed to end. This was very clearly written by two men with little to no understanding of the feminine experience. Lest we forget the addition of absurd frat boy humor that adds nothing of value to the movie.

This is a movie that doesn't know what it wants to be. It straddles about eight different genres with lots of flash and very little substance. At 2 hours, 18 minutes, it's way too long. It gets great reviews from people who are dazzled by it's barrage of effects and unique style, but when you come right down to it, there's very little "there" there. Imagine going out for a great meal and being served pasta with tomato sauce, hot dogs, peanut butter, pickles, egg foo young, anchovies, Cheez Whiz, and jell-o — all mixed together on an everything bagel. That's what you'll get when you watch this.

So then, the rare negative reviews... curiously,  these are to be embraced -- feel as if driven, in some cases, by the very attachments the movie seeks to indict; others, trouble understanding what the hell is going on; still others, simply aversion to the goofiness.  (The googleyness?)  Taking these in while still on the movie high, unexpectedly, is as moving as the title I just watched.

Well, first of all I have to congratulate the editor of this movie for what was probably the most difficult editing job in the history of cinema. Absolutely amazing and mind boggling! The story is surely the weirdest and craziest I have seen in many years, though in all its oddity there seems to be some sense and modern day reasoning with a bit of love and the message that we all just have to enjoy our lives as they are the result of our own decisions in the past and that it makes no damn sense to cry about spilled milk. All in all it is a lot of fun, between wild action and silly comedy. It's a one of its kind movie and just for that already worth watching though I am sure that many people will find it too confusing and chaotic. Well, I like chaos, so I had a good time. 7 1/2 of 10 points.

Such an amazing movie.  It's not what it seems that it is about, and it is almost impossible to describe.  It is visually amazing, the costumes are inventive and incredible, the editing is like I've never seen the acting is unmatched in any movie and the screenplay is profound.  How you can end up bawling your eyes out about two rocks on a cliff with subtitles is beyond me, and yet - there it is. You can't help but love and care about every character.  It is a mother daughter movie, it's about conflicts between generations - espcially in the Asian community, it is a love story and not just between husband and wife but between more complicated relationships.  It is about what if.  It is about the road not taken.  And it takes on multigeneraltional trauma and changing the narrative (a word I never say, but it is the right word).
This was so crazy and I absolutely loved it! For all of you who haven't seen it hold on because you are about to fly through this movie!

What's amazing about this film is the ability of the actors to breath life into bad writing and shallow character development.  In too many places the script is incredibly long-winded and the underlying sentiment trite.  Depth is replaced by rapid pacing and absurdity, which seems to have worked for a lot of the audience. However, remove those stylistic choices and there's not really much story or even setting here, and what is on offer is unfocused and shallow. A lot of spagetti was thrown at the wall to see what sticks; some see a brilliant pattern in the mess, others will just see the mess.  I loved the Daniels' debut film, Swiss Army Man, which has similar absurdist qualities but in service of a focused, thoughtful script and conclusion that really did surprise and satisfy.  This film fails to achieve the same result.
This movie is creative, surprising, charming, heart wrenching and hysterically funny. A fun rollercoaster of a watch.

This film feels like a warm hug for younger generation, as it embraces the loneliness of internet overstimulation and desperation for parental acceptance and even loving approval. The fact that the most emotionally moving scene in this film is depicted by two rocks attests to its brilliant writing. Like stacking stones, this film mindfully balances its exploration of existentialism, immigrant identity, generational divide, poverty, and even the multiverse through its stunning and cheeky visuals. I laughed, I cried, I craved bagels.

unexpected and refreshing take on the unlikely superhero theme

Usually I avoid things that get entirely too much hype, but this may be the one pop culture moment that absolutely lives up to everything I'd heard in advance. You know how some movies are Out to Make Big Statements And Change Your Life and it's too self-aware of how profound it's attempting to be to be enjoyable? This is the antidote for that. Watching this movie is a joyful thrill ride from start to finish with deep existential questions posed within the framework of heart and humor. That it shifted my lens on my life a little isn't as important as noting that the film is a spectacle of visual imagery and shockingly adept acting; this may be the best supporting ensemble I've ever seen in my life and nobody plays small or half-ass. Everyone is real and relatable and beautiful and I keep watching this film and emerging feeling like I took my brain to the playground.

The concept is good, especially if you liked watching old Chinese kung fu movies back in the day... It's definitely not everyone's cup of tea, and it may not keep your interest if you don't care about the multiverse scenario. Especially when there is no cool CGI like in the Avengers movies. I'm actually surprised so many people rate this movie so high which is really cool... Anybody over 55 years old probably won't care for this movie and probably won't understand the concept.

Just to start this off I want to say that this is for sure the best movie of 2022, I have two problems with this movie one of them being the beginning starts off a bit slow but it was quickly paced much better. The cinemaphotography is amazing, comedy was great and perfectly timed, and the action scenes were near perfect. The actors were chosen well but the character writing made the movie 10x better. Really wanted to like this movie since I really liked the cast.  The makes of this movie tried to add too much to it and it became a bloated mess that went on way too long. There were a few funny parts, and I think the actors did fine jobs, but the script was out of control and I didn't feel that it ever resolved in a satisfying way.

How much I liked the characters and performances and humor in this movie, and the underlying theme was wonderful. I can see why so many people love this movie. 

But, for me, it was waaaaaayyyyy too long. I was 90 minutes in wondering how much longer it was going to go on, and still I had another hour to endure. Where I knew what the ending was going to be, had already gotten the message, understood the endearing motifs, but the parallel universes kept coming and returning and I was just thinking, "Oh my god, get me out of here!" 

Thankfully, the ending and the (wonderful) outtakes put a nice cherry on top for a nice smile while leaving the theater, but I'll never watch this movie again. Honestly, I felt the same during "Mother," a similar type of well-made less-humorous movie that was heavy on theme/parable and that I also found difficult to endure. So clearly it's me. I do better when the theme is delivered with a little more realism and less outrageousness, like "Don't Look Up." But, again, I can see why people love this movie, and why our tickettaker has watched the movie four times.

I'm pretty blown away by this movie, it's unlike anything I've ever experienced. Probably the most insane, weird, hectic, overwhelming, beautiful, immersive thing I've ever seen. Every creative decision was so original and impressive while also being extremely transportive. It's somehow able to be so incredibly over the top and insane while also telling a deeply personal story with swelling emotions. Literally everything about this is top tier and it's one of those films that transcends genre to create something that only itself could be. You could easily look at this on a surface level and say it's too weird and confusing, but that's quite literally the point; there are no rules. Nothing matters, yet we still choose love and kindness. The movie does such a good job of not just telling you or showing you this theme, but transporting you into it. Already one of my favorites all time.

An interdimensional fight against evil imposed over a battle between nihilism (Sarté) and absurdism (Camus), imposed over a touching story of the struggles of a normal 21st-century immigrant family grappling with intergenerational trauma, also it's a an absurd comedy + Kung Fu movie with Michelle Yeoh, and it's Ke Huy Quan's first film since Indiana Jones and The Goonies. Are you sold yet? My only warning is that it's not for people who don't like bizarre physical comedy, as this goes to similarly weird places as Swiss Army Man by the same director duo.

I've never felt as much sameness with a character in media as I did with Waymond. The scene that's a nod to In The Mood For Love, where he says "This is how I fight," fixed something I didn't realize was broken in me. I both laughed until my face hurt and cried real tears multiple times. This movie changed my perspective on life, I saw it when it first came out and I still feel different to this day.

Buzzwords:

Kung-Fun / Moving Story / Beautiful Visuals

Reminds of or watch alongside:

- The Princess Bride - Similar family fun, with some fantastic action, and a heartwarming story that keeps you rooting for its characters' adventures!

- The Matrix - Chose this due to its use of the multiverse/anything can happen rhetoric and acquiring skills from the experiences shared/learnt via a headset. Oh, and it definitely throws some punches!

- Kung-Fu Hustle - For those who want more silly Kung-Fu fun. That coincidentally also has a lovely story and can appeal to a wide audience. Notably, in my opinion, Hustle is one of the few films where the dubbed version is my preferred method of watching - as an English-speaking viewer.

"In my opinion...":

A24 did not disappoint with this release. Starting slow to help you learn the roles of the characters. 

As I am not an Asian living in the US, I still found this film to be engaging and allow audience members to share the experiences of each character through the medium of the multiverse segments. 

Also includes scenes that relate to the dynamics of every family's peaks and troths: love, becoming misunderstood/estranged, and the battle to uphold their roles in the relationships that are shared between them. 

And then. 'Everything...' moulds itself into the fun and ridiculous. I was captivated and felt connected to the multiple story arcs that are presented to us. Always returning to its 'That is just silly' method.

This film will make you laugh and cry. I was utterly captivated. 

Although, it does have A LOT to say. I can understand why some viewers may be put off by the ever-changing pace, a complex sci-fi environment and it does help to have some awareness of Asian culture within the US to fully grasp its messages.

Other than that:

Come for the hotdogs, stay for the punches.

I am trying to reconcile my, admittedly high, expectations, against the movie I actually saw. The acting here was mostly great. Michelle Yeon and Stephanie Hsu were perfectly cast, though Ke Huy Quan (IMO) outshone them both. Jamie Lee Curtis and veteran actor James Hong were also solid. The first half was pretty entertaining.
Then things just got weird, and not good weird. More like absurd, and then just gross for the sake of it. This didn't feel like a multiverse, it felt like being trapped in an X-rated version of the Infinite Improbability Drive. 
Dildos and butt plugs aside, it was just unimaginative and gross. Hot dog fingers?? Who thinks this is interesting? Seriously, how does this stuff get past any group brainstorming meeting?
The idea, that a woman who is good at nothing might be the one person good enough to save everyone, AND the core story of a deeply flawed mother-daughter relationship at the center of a multi-verse spinning out of control, had the potential to be fantastic.
Sadly, we only got flashes of that could-be brilliant movie in-between reems of barf-inducing nonsense.

Michele Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu,  Ke Huy Quan, and Jamie Lee Curtis are standouts in a very strong cast. The Daniels (Kwan and Scheinert) who wrote and directed the film (and did it on amazingly low $25 million, given the product) have created a great work of art.

The script had only 2 possibilities given its scope and subject matter, to be absolutely awful or absolutely brilliant.
