Happy endings it has but life lessons, like Disney, if fails miserably.
Theme: your messed up, not a little but at narcissistically satisfying levels – not global.  No, that's not big enough. The child protagonist is messed up at multidimensional levels throughout the universe.  What could be bigger?  What could be more narcissistic and sadder?  Oh, and to top it off there are extra helping of "It's all how your parents brought you up – not really your fault you poor precious, self-destructive thing." theme.  One can argue that the great Guardians of the Galaxy has a similar subplot. Ok, but 1) it isn't the main theme and 2) the story doesn't take place on earth in modern times with people who are supposed to relate to.  Guardians of the Galaxy is clearly fantasy whereas the characters in this movie are meant to be relatable and, to a unhealthy person, a bit too real.
Mass shootings anyone?  It's got plenty along with vulgar sex toy murders and blood and …why waste time telling you more?  "Nothing matters" as is repeatedly proclaimed in self-destructive justification.  That it excretes a happy ending simply confirms the sad delusion of those who envisioned the story.  There are a lot of special effects – intentional sensory overload - that do a good job confusing the sane viewer of what the heck is going on.  It feels essentially like a story written by a self-destructive person who wants to take the universe down with them to make their mother suffer deeply so that she will regret it then magically reverse the destruction across multiple fantasy dimension which the child has caused.  That is one messed up story line.
I worry that this is trying to normalize disfunction.  The only redemption is very good acting and special effects.  The movie, and perhaps writers lacked a good psychotherapist.
The honesty is human emotions, how the failures were apparent but not insurmountable- it felt like hope.
Really refreshing film. I really enjoyed it.

Tour De Force.  As if the Matrix could be re-incarnated, now half breed, holding both the memories of Neo and that of Charles Frost.  The digitally aware self meets the self reminiscent, combine that with the duality of the chaos and order of life, and you have a brilliant film.  Humor intertwines this epic tale of life; equal parts tormentor, and angelic savior, the main character bouts with not only their internal narrative, but also that which seems to order and disorder the universe.  Intermixed with this narrative is a parents look at their own dreams through the life of their daughter, who becomes their own duality.  Projecting the dreams of one onto the decisions of another.  Once again chaos intervenes.  This repeats itself until the creator relents, the protagonists find peace, and two rocks find moments to simply be in the existence.  This would be a fine place to be, if not for the chaos of life drawing one to be more than just a rock, but to be both active and aware, not only presently but infinitely.  And that is the conundrum of what it means to be human.  To be Everything, Everywhere, All At Once.  Aware of who you are now, what it took to bring you to today, all of the possibilities that could have made up to tomorrow, and you here we are now, experiencing it, all at once.  This movie could define a generation and yet define everyone.  Like Citizen Kane, or The Matrix, Everything, Everywhere, All at Once provides a glimpse at what it means to exist with more knowledge than ever, of what our existence could have been, meanwhile in our actual existence, we are in ever more demand, if only we were present to feel and absorb what that should mean to, both the ying and the yang.  The order and the chaos, the joy and the pain.  The duality of mans existence.  Rarely does a movie summarize such valuable truths, and ever rare is it that said truths are displayed in a captivating and visually entertaining narrative.  I fear only that we won't really understand what it means, but then again, why should anyone be so silly as to assume they do.

‘The Matrix in The Multiverse of Madness', that's a description that feels both fitting and yet entirely undersells this multi-faceted feast for the senses, and boy, is it absurdly good. Like controlled chaos exploding across the screen, ‘Everything Everywhere All At Once' pays homage to many other great films, but if there's one thing you can say about it, it's that it certainly does its own thing. The result is something with a bit of everything: creative visuals, action and humour, but also has a powerful human core whose heartfelt, deeper messages effectively penetrate all the madness. The cast do a superb job – both Stephanie Hsu and Jamie Lee Curtis are great, and it's really nice to see Ke Huy Quan on the silver screen again -- but this is Michelle Yeoh's show and she gets her chance to shine like a crazy diamond. This is a unique, wild, fun and touching ride, and there's about a million ways this couldn't and probably shouldn't have worked, but Daniels have outdone themselves to deliver something truly spectacular. One of the most enjoyable films I've seen in recent memory.

It's so bad it's great. I say that because, at least based on what I got from it, it's about the human psyche and how we think. We are always thinking about different things and sometimes things that contradict one another. As the title says, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is how people think, even if we don't think we think that way. 

The movie can be extremely confusing and even gave me a slight headache but that's because, based on what I think, our brain tries to wrap itself around everything that was going on, but it's impossible for it to do so because it's so vast with all the different things. I don't even know how they came up with this movie because, in my head, it's impossible yet possible. It's hard to comprehend. One of the best things about this movie though is that it can be interpreted in many different ways. I don't even know if it's intended for this effect on the viewers of the movie.

If my review is confusing or doesn't make sense, let me put it in simple terms. If you ever thought about what the human psyche looks like in a movie, watch this.

That's all why it's so bad it's great.

Easily one of the most visually striking and conceptually original films of the 21st century, Everything Everywhere All At Once may have a cumbersome title, and an occasionally confusing to the point of tedium storyline, but its chock full of incredible ingenuity and genuine emotional weight. Michelle Yeoh, who in the last few years is finally getting the recognition she deserves, plays a downtrodden laundromat owner who is introduced to the secrets of the multiverse. The film has a similar problem to Inception and Tenet, in that the story is so complicated that lengthy scenes of exposition are required, and even those can make it feel more difficult to comprehend. But as the story progress you do develop something of a handle on things, and when you grasp the core concepts the film really comes into its own. I loved the way it handled themes of nihilism, family acceptance and the importance of understanding a person despite their differences, and while the middle section of the film can feel long and directionless at times, as it enters the 3rd act the film delivers some serious emotional gut punches, and everything that we've seen falls into place. The actors do a great job, the script is funny, insightful and cleverly constructed, and the lessons we learn come about completely organically. It's a film that many will find hard to digest, but if the cinematic medium is going to continue to evolve, we need films that are going to push boundaries and break new ground, and that's what this one does. If you can embrace its wackiness and accept its unconventionality, then you're in for a real treat.
absolutely perfect! this film has a crazy idea but totally make sense. some scene confusing me but in the end it make me cry!!!

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a wonderful absurdist comedy about a tired laundromat owner who suddenly gets pulled into the multiverse and becomes an unlikely hero. Excellent performances from the ensemble cast, especially Michelle Yeoh. It was great to see Ke Huy Quan (Goonies and Indiana Jones) back on the big screen. Jamie Lee Curtis was great as always, and Stephanie Hsu was stunning in her role. Excellently choreographed Kung Fu fight sequences reminiscent of Kill Bill. The movie also borrows some ideas from The Matrix as well as other other science fiction movies. It's wonderful mix of different genres. There's action, comedy, drama and thriller. It is absurd, action-packed, wonderful, outrageous, sad, profound and hilarious all at once! It's so good, it became an instant classic for me. One of the best movies to come out this year.  Definitely worth watching!

The transition from mundane life to verse jumping, psychedelic trips to across timelines left me a bit unnerved and overwhelmed but in a good way, kinda. The movie was packed with action, comparable to a Marvel movie --hmm, makes me wonder which brothers helped to produce it. 

The scene that stood out to me the most was the existential bit when Waymond explains how his way of exercising human freedom and choice in the midst of the abyss of 'everything' is to express kindness. This had me feeling all sentimental and soft, lol. 

Overall, great movie and excellent acting! :)

The reason some people score low or didn't like it was generally because they can't keep up.  The movie is about an average Asian American family so they jump quickly in an out of Chinese and English using subtitles.  You have to be able to follow both to understand. If you can get past the switching and the chaos it's an amazing story of family relationships deteriorating and being rebuilt through love and kindness.

There are not enough stars in this universe for this movie. I was absolutely not prepared. It's what you think it is about and it isn't. It is the weirdest, dumbest, dadaist film, that is the best date movie I've been to in years and absolutely life affirming in a way that a more mainstream film simply couldn't be.
It took me about an hour in to really get what the filmmakers were doing, but from then on I was in love with this film.

Everything Everywhere All At Once
In just about every sense, this movie delivered what the title promised. It's so easy to get sucked into with all there is to appreciate about it. Michelle Yeoh leads the cast in her portrayal of Evelyn Quan and her multiverse counterparts. The version of her we focus on is a middle-aged mother who immigrated to the United States from China with her husband, Waymond Wang. They own a laundromat, raise a daughter, struggle to pay bills and spend their days daydreaming of all the things that could have been, while trying to find some level of joy in each other. Evelyn has revelations about herself and her motherhood, largely to her daughter Joy, played by Stephanie Hsu - a now-adult who is very different but also, in so many ways, an image of her. Hsu does a good job at playing all the different versions of herself, with emotional vulnerability, depth, and emotional range. The character felt very raw, real, and there was lot to explore about her.
The editing did a brilliant job in illustrating an incredibly believable multi-dimensional world all colliding into these characters' love for each other extending across space and time. As the aspect ratio shifts, the tone switches; in 16:9, it breaks itself from the world and switches into a more comic-book feel. The characters are almost in a cartoon and this makes this medium and theme an engaging way to tell the story. Not a whole lot of CGI editing was used in this movie but they still did a really good job at accomplishing a fantastical world and all its different possibilities and timelines. The repetition of the front desk marks the beginning of each chapter while representing a story that goes backwards and forwards in time and space, yet is experienced by one character sequentially. The emotional depth makes everyone watching feel seen in their raw humanity.

What a strange movie. I need to watch it again! Even as multiverse movies have become more familiar over the past four years, this one stands apart from all the others in that we see parallel universes at the same time. The way this is handled is incredible and makes for some interesting story elements and some amazing visuals. Being able to see Evelyn conscious of herself in two universes simultaneously was clever, trippy, and as the move goes on, very chaotic. At time there's numerous characters doing this at the same time and it's just bonkers. In the end the story is quite simple and has a good message, but the journey is such a fun time!

The creativity in some of these scenes is often so insane that it's just hilarious. The actions required to transport from one universe to another, to gain a particular skill or ability, can be painful to watch and sometimes so absurd that it will, without a doubt, spark laughter. I love the story it tells, the emotions it kindled, and was such a fun theater experience. If I had to complain about anything it would be the runtime as it felt long at times even though it was never boring. Still, this is just one week away from being released on disc and I look forward to adding it to my physical media collection.
That's what I said. Booby traps!

Easily could be movie of the year. Marvel could never dream of making a multiverse movie this good. It was thrilling, philosophical, funny, and yet touching as many of the people in the theatre ended up crying. A hidden gem for sure that will probably make a lot of people want to be better.

🏳️‍🌈 An absurdist comedy-drama starring the marvelous Michelle Yeoh 楊紫瓊, who brilliantly portrays an aging Chinese immigrant trying to do her taxes who discovers that she must connect with parallel universe versions of herself to prevent a powerful being from causing the destruction of the multiverse. It features elements of black comedy, science fiction, fantasy, martial arts film and animation and it is as insane as a movie can get. The imagination of the directors and writers, the Daniels, is just out-of-this-world and themes such as existentialism, nihilism, Asian-American identity and even LGBTQ acceptance are included. This is a movie with stunning visuals, not to be taken seriously, or literally for that matter. Just enjoy the Matrix-like mayhem this movie is supposed to be, because it truly lives up to its title.
It is a rare but amazing movie.

Jaimie Lee Curtis just make everything work in every frame all the time showing not only her dramatic skills but her always fine tuned comic chops. A must see!

This movie is incredible and visually stunning and no its not always going to make sense, but why should it? When the core of the movie is about the estranged relationships within a family struggling to keep ends meet, you can afford to deviate from that stale premise by taking us on a crazy ride through the multiverse! (This is how you do it Dr Strange 2 !) This is creativity unbound and I love to see this kind of uniqueness in movies as it seems lacking with the usual "blockbuster" cookie-cutter fodder that is being dished out. So grab your snacks, get comfy in your house, and stick this movie on and enjoy the crazy ride! but don't insist on every little inconsequential detail being explained to you because life would be boring if nothing was left to the imagination.

I don't think I've ever seen a better representation of how it feels to watch your child struggle with depression/suicidal thoughts- the guilt, the fierce love, the desperate clinging and determination to keep them safe by sheer will alone, and the excruciating acceptance that despite all the will in the world, they have to be the ones to take the steps back from the void.  I know that there was a lot more jam packed into this movie, but this is what resonated the most with me.

Your life has manifested you in one of many ways, but they are all running concurrently right now .. can you feel it ? By that token the motivation of the villain is weak so then the story is weak. This person finds "love" is "happy", has hard working "parents" who really have their own problems, but their inability to cope with the fact that everyone even people close to you will not love everything about you nor everything you do. Unfortunately this movie is good only for mindless watching but truthfully there's nothing to see here.

This film must be the most overrated film in a long time, maybe there is just a very strong need for Asian representation in cinema? I mean that is understandable since the last film like this was crazy Rich Asians and you can hardly say that represented Asian people accurately. 
I think the bigger reason for its popularity is that it spoke to many who found it meaningful. Unfortunately I was not one of those people.
Don't get me wrong, Michelle Yeoh is fantastic in this role it really lets you see her talent in a new way, but the story is not only preposterous, even for a sci-fi lover like myself, the movie so desperately wants to be meaningful but in my opinion fails miserably. 
I am obviously Lonewolf here given the ratings for this film and acclaim from so many people not just Asians, but as a 'deep thinker' and spiritual person in pursuit of constant improvement and personal development, to me the message in this film is just laughable, it said nothing and it was not inspiring at all. In my opinion it also makes Asian children raised in America seem lost, useless and foolish.
Maybe I am just too jaded and find many films and series that try to be meaningful and incorporate spiritual elements fail miserably, Raised By Wolves included. I think it's just a symptom of a lack of true spiritual awareness in the world and it's too frustrating to me.
But don't listen to me you'll probably love this film like everyone else.

I immensely enjoyed "Everything Everywhere All at Once". In the battle of Multiverses, this film easily takes down "Dr. Strange 2". I found it very weird, very funny, very inventive, very engaging, and ever so entertaining. Despite all the weirdness, it has a comprehensible story and a heartfelt relationships that makes the viewer engages and cares deeply about all the characters, and Michelle Yeoh is giving the performance(s) of her life. She is just so amazing in every irritation of Evelyn from all universe. That's not to say it's all about her, as the movie gives Stephanie Tsu who plays her daughter Joy, Key Huy Quan who plays her husband Waymond, the great James Hung playing her father Gong Gong, and Jamie Lee Curtis who plays Deirdre fantastic supporting roles that span multiuniverses. It's one of the movies that will forever define 2022 and I am glad it's as successful as it is because it deserves it.

There is a lot to love about this film and I would love to see other original movies being made in the same vein. However I feel the third act/finale is a bit longwinded, trying to hammer in the point to the audience which lessened the impact for me personally. But overall a solid watch with solid performances and its uniqueness is something worthy of praise.

I don't how else to describe it other than "special". It's an instant classic, people will talk about this movie forever, and not the tecnicalities (although also) but it touches you, it touched me and everyone I know who watched. It speaks with everyone (everywhere all at once ha ha).

"Everything Everywhere All at Once " tells the story of a laundress owner who experiences a rupture in the multiverse and has to deal with the bizarre dangers that multiple realities bring. The feature exudes creativity and treats family relationships in such a fun way, not to mention the direction that from the transitions to the positioning of cameras demonstrates personality and grace, the photography is magnificent and the passages between the universes are wonderful, but my expectations after reading several reviews they were too big and because they were big the movie ended up not being able to overcome and the feeling of frustration after the movie came because no matter how cool, deep and creative I didn't get excited or had as much fun as I thought I would.

Extremely entertaining, funny, emotional deconstruction of family crisis and growth dealing with life of female Chinese immigrant who is dealing with too many troubles at once. A comedy with depth and emotion. Not a propaganda piece for any agenda even though definitely touching on social sensitive issues like having a gay daughter, dealing with older immigrant generation perspective on today's society, and all mixed with insane sci-fi and multi-verse notions but through a sharp hilarious perspective.

While "Everything Everywhere All at Once" starts off at a slow pace with too much information to process at once, these flaws are gradually fixed and become difficult to remember due to an exceptional cast and unmatched visuals. Not only does this film exquisitely demonstrate the importance of living in the moment and reminding our loved ones how indispensable they are, but its sentimental and thought-provoking themes also make it worth watching.
I loved everything, absolutely everything about this film. It had everything I love in and didn't know I could love in a film A24 kills each and everytime.
Truly one of the worst things I've ever seen.

This is my favorite movie of the year, maybe even the decade.  The filmmakers really know how to tackle deep, heavy thoughts, and combine them with everyday hilarious subjects.  I'm have a feeling I'm gonna watch this thing over and over for years to come.

At heart, this film is just an A24-style Brave, Lady Bird, or even Freaky Friday. I.E. a tale of a mother + daughter’s growing pains. This film doesn’t make sense, and it doesn’t try to, it just wraps you up in its visually, as well as spiritually awakening, stunning tale of a mother learning to not make the same mistakes her father made with her daughter, and that’s enough for me.
Not a new concept, but still creative within the multiverse idea. The script is comical, whimsical and witty, meanwhile having an overarching message/purpose. Excellent movie!
Rick & Morty + Ratatouille on steroids.  If you like both titles then this movie will fit you like a glove.
A great and pointed antidote to the cynical times in which we live.

Oh boy, where do I start with this one? Very original, very inspired, funny and clever, with a message to all generations, but especially resonating with mine owns (I am a millennial/gen Z hybrid). All of this is great and makes it one of the freshest movies of the year. But there is one thing in all that fun mess that did not sit right with me. Let's talk about the tone of "Everything Everywhere All At Once", because, well – it's weird. Not, I get the tonal shifts are part of the joke here, part of the identity of this movie. But still, some of them... Ugh. Maybe that's them cultural differences again, but some parts of the movie, rather than funny felt simply in bad taste to me. It's not totally family friendly and that was very unexpected to me, with all that inter-generational message and all. Eh well. Maybe I'm being unreasonable here again. But I still think that the movie would be much better without the distasteful stuff.
Not what I expected going in and I loved it! Must watch!

Mind-boggling, visually stunning and carrying a deep and beautiful message (one that might be easy to miss amidst all the chaos), this film will really blow your mind and surpass your wildest expectations. The entire cast is brilliant, led by the amazing Michelle Yeoh.
So refreshing to see such an original film.  Loved it!!!

A nice message/moral with great fight sequences, costumes, and native Chinese language/songs. Some humor is polarizing and some topics, as well. Would see again. A better multiverse movie than spider man and dr strange.

One of the greatest movies I have every seen.
Trippy, eye-opening, thought-provoking, poignantly funny, breathtakingly great acting. Check it out!

What a change in pace from Hollywood. This movie was hands down a major studio type film produced by a smalle, independent studio. In the era of BIG, LOUD and CRAZY, this was perfect in capturing your attention.

A stunningly original, wildly inventive, gloriously insane movie that scores points for being much more committed to its multiverse-themed premise than Doctor Strange 2, Everything Everywhere All At Once is a hilarious, heartfelt, thought-provoking adventure with a great performance from Michelle Yeoh and some impressively choreographed martial arts fight scenes (Yeoh having to fight two guys to prevent them from shoving butt-plug-shaped trophies up their asses is the scene that will probably make or break this movie for you. If you weren't into it, chances are this isn't the movie for you) making this not just one of the best films of 2022 but also one of the most creative sci-fi films of all time.
amazing visuals. A stunning performance by Michelle Yeoh. Highly recommended

Such an overrated film. Creative and pretty original but people are acting like it’s godfather 2. It’s very heavy handed, and only people that have extreme doubt/depression in their lives might find it relatable.

Really entertaining and inspiring!   If you have the right mindset and  heartset it's one of the best movies you'll ever watch.  Just muster the first 25 minutes and look past the ridiculousness, which ends up being a necessity.
I am 100% positive that all these “good” reviews were left because the reviewer didn’t want others to believe they didn’t “get” the film and its art and themes. Just be honest. It was boring.

One of the absolute best movies that has come out in recent years. The incredible script, editing, and acting cannot be understated. The movie deals with philosophical nihilism in a way that is easily accessible for all (adult/older teen) audiences, and it makes its case in response so earnestly and effectively that you can't help but love it. I would call Ke Huy Quan a standout performance in the movie if it weren't for the fact that literally every actor in the movie is at the top of their game. There are concepts so strange that you never would have imagined them, yet will have you tearing up when it all pays off. If you have not seen it yet, you are missing out.

This is the real multiverse of madness. Complex, frantic, emotional with family issues thrown in. I'd imagine any fellow first-generation Asian kids feel some relatability to the family in this movie, in terms of understanding parents' assimilation to a new culture while trying to grasp onto the culture that the parents come from. The sci-fi aspect of this movie bridges the familial misunderstandings in a touching and heartwrenching way that had me sobbing in the theater. The movie may feel all over the place, but that's kinda the point--have you read the title? Patience pays off.
Quite shocking, and quite amusing all at once. Almost like I'm in different multiverses.
Loved this movie.   Crazy story, really takes you on a journey, so much detail and it really made me laugh a lot in various parts!    Very original and imaginative!

There's a lot to like about this film; the frenetic pace, the fight sequences, the sly humour, the acting, direction, script and editing.  There is a shower of cultural references that often go over the head, but give an added zest to a second viewing.  My complaint is the length. At over 2 hours, it's exhausting and demands too much on the viewer who tires from the cavalcade of events and misses the quality script.  This is not a film to be seen in the cinema: it needs to be stopped and returned to after the brain has rested.
Its good but not for all its famiky and emotional

This is literally one of the best movie of the year! I gotta give a major props to Michelle Yeoh’s performance and the rest of the casts. The visuals, the music, and the cinematographer blew me out of this movie. Gotta watch again.
Perhaps the worst film I have seen since Synecdoche, New York.  I would have left early but just did not want to squeeze past people - though they were yawning way more than I was.....

This movie really is something else, dealing with super complex and thought provoking themes in a weird and hilarious way. Everything works, the characters, the editing, the directing, the music, the story, the costumes. Perfectly balancing drama with comedy. This is the most creative movie I have ever seen, a definite must see 10/10
So Damon confusing and bizarre.

Exceeded absolutely every expectation I could have had, and I went in with none going in.

The film is high-paced, entertaining, original in more ways than one and a cast with more chemistry than I expected.

The lessons and meaning provided by the screenplay are timeless, as the film is itself. More importantly, it was delivered in a way that's funny but not cheesy whatsoever.

It also reminded me of a lesser-known film called "Mr Nobody" from 2009.
A mix of "Minha mãe é uma peça", produced by the legendary Paulo Gustavo, and "Lucy". Its an epic and phenomenal masterpiece.

I could not believe how dumb, boring, and annoying this movie was, after seeing the reviews.  Question is this place becoming like the reviews for hotels, all fake, no way is this movie great, Saw it wife, i asked her, she said was not good as well, make you think

It is like the writer of this movie was a big fan of sliders, quantum leap, the matrix and Rick and Morty. They essentially take all these ideas and mash them together with a little bit of kung fu and cheap potty humor. (I mean wow, the jokes were soo bad in this movie I felt embarrassed) Predictable plot line (main story line if you can call it that) and unleavable (and mostly silly/stupid) action.

Michelle also doesn't deliver in this, the action is great (but completely unbelievable) , but her acting and delivery of her lines is lacking of emotion and believability, I still don't think she is a very good actress.

I really wanted to like this movie but it was lacking in most respects, the entire movie was full of moments i've already seen in so many other movies and shows that it felt repeated and boring. I don't understand why so many people are giving this such high reviews. (I was also constantly taken out of the movie with over the top action scenes or failed attempts at humour)

I'm adding this after the fact, there are many moments in the show that actually have no grounding in reality. Yes I know it's science fiction, but it was based in our reality, with our physics and laws. How can a women who has never worked out, thrown a punch, done a pushup suddenly able to jump off walls and throw people around. Sure she has the knowledge and skill, but not the muscle mass or body. There is one moment she throws a POLICE SHEILD like its captain Americas shield, hits multiple people and then proceeds to catch it. Completely took me out of the moment, and there are a lot of these moments. I know I'm supposed to suspend my believes for movies but this just takes it too far. They try to be the matrix but fail hard. You cant just suddenly know how to weightlift and do it. IT DOESN'T WORK LIKE THAT.

This movie has so many borrowed ideas and stolen moments from other shows and movies its embarrassing, this is only the directors second actual movie and really shows how they should have stuck to music videos. Yes people will argue there are no new stories, well this movie goes to prove that.

The sad part is so many people enjoy this goes to show how out of touch people are and how starved they are for something different even if its a heaping pile of garbage.

Michelle Yeoh gives an exceptional performance, taking the audience on just as big an adventure as the film itself. The film balances life's many themes and questions admits the chaos of the multiverse with a sense of heart.

Probably the most surprising film I've ever seen. Another addition to the list of movies that I would like to forget to rewatch.

Note: watch it in the big screen if you can :)
At this moment there are several movies about the multiverse, but this is definitely the most profound and intelligent one with a beautiful message to our mankind and an excellent work of the actors.
the overall message of acceptance and love while also allowing others to accept and love themselves is brilliant. a beautiful message of learning to be present

It was bad. The idea for the movie seemed good and interesting enough, but this movie was not! It was pointless & very boring. It also had the kind of stupid childish humor only an 8-15 year old would find funny (hotdog fingers in mouths). Parts where kind of gross (bloody dildo fight). Dumb shock value crap that did nothing to further the little story it had. the characters had no real depth and came off stereotypical to me. I would of turned it off but my bf wanted to finish watching it. He fell asleep, I was not so lucky. It did not get better, this movie was pointless, stupid and it completely lacked anything original or interesting or inspiring. I think the movie tried really hard to pull together some kind of inspiring message at the end which was, wait for it;…. "Be kind to people" a very kid poster on a wall in a kindergarten classroom kindof message. I liked the sentiment but That was the best they could come up with and the film doesn't even deliver that message very well, it never really comes together. Nothing ground breaking here, It was not unique or inspiring in anyway… just a pile of junk. If your not really high or an 8 to 15 year old boy, I would say skip this movie and go watch something else. I really wanted to like this movie but I honestly can't find anything good to say about it. I guess I thought the actors did a good job with what they were given which wasn't much (really not a whole lot of dialog in this film).  But even the fight scenes, which I normally like in movies, were just ruined because of this films attempt at humor. Not only was it not funny, it took away from the action too. All of this is just my opinion and if you liked the film thats cool. Everybody doesn't have to like the same things. Peace ✌️.
BEST MOVIE I have ever seen!!!
A touching story, great acting, thought-provoking philosophical musings, and incredibly creative visuals make this a must see. And yes, we need to be kind to each other.

A breathtaking multidimensional journey into oneself.
Amazing movie. Truly a must see.
This is my favorite film of the year so far. I’ve seen a lot of great movies, but this one is exceptionally original, thought provoking, fun, and meaningful- all at the same time.
Honestly didn't not enjoy this at all, I know comedy is subjective but found it all to be just weird at over the top, sausage fingers really???
I was looking forward to this movie because of the great reviews, but I couldn’t make it past 45 mins. Movie was all over the place.
que gran película, es una belleza audiovisual sobre el amor y la aceptación. Bizarra, graciosa y romántica pero muy original. Btw, este es el verdadero multiverso.

I bought this movie for $19.99 because it was rated 95 on Rotten Tomatoes. I compared its score to one of my favorite movies, Arrival, which had a 94 and thought this would be really good. Nope! It was painful, and I could only blame myself.
For all the chaos and "wtf-ery" you have to sit through to reach the end of the movie, there's never a satisfying reveal or point where it pays off. It's all for nothing. Meaningless. A waste of time. You've been warned. 

My rating system goes like this:
5 - loved it, spread the word
4 - liked it
3 - meh, unmoved, unaffected.
2 - disliked it
1- hated it, spread the word

If you've ever suffered from nihilism, depression, anxiety about what it all means, pain, loss of hope, wondering about what could be, etc. you must see this movie. It really felt like having the slate wiped clean in my brain in a lot of ways. I had high hopes for this movie even though I try not to ever do that, but man did it not disappoint. Wow!! What a fantastic funny and profound film.  Bonkers and genius rolled into a mesmerising 2.5hrs.  I actually didn't want it to stop and was disappointed when the credits rolled.  Would have happily sat there and watched  it immediately again.
What an original movie. Equal parts action, humor, and emotion. It has something for everyone.

The film's title is self-explanatory. A multi-layered film that touches on multiple subjects, but addresses each one with a good script, a strong cast and the right type of humour to balance out its seemingly hopeless story. One of this year's best. Once again, thank you, A24.
OMG terrible. Super confusing. Waste of 2.5 hrs. Watch Top Gun instead.

imagina que un niño de 10 años, superdotado intelectual y emocionalmente haya tenido la más grandiosa epifanía sobre el significado de la vida, mientras está en medio de una pelea de payasos en su cumpleaños. Eso es esta película y más! Solo véanla. Y si, esta reseña es en español, porque se me cantaron los huevos.
Iconic, best movie of the year by far!
Absolutely splendid and stupidly funny. In fact, this is what I describe as the real multiverse of madness😉. I absolutely loved it from the bottom of my heart.

A wild ride that was highly entertaining. Michelle Yeoh is absolutely fantastic (who hasn't loved her since Crouching Tiger?) Ke Huy Quan playing her sometimes here, sometimes there husband was another great casting choice. With 'Multiverse" stories being the in-thing at the moment, this one takes you on a fresh and hilarious journey. Well done.

I honestly didn't have high hopes for this one when I saw the trailer. It felt like it was try to cash in on the multiverse fad in a subpar way. I am happy to say that I was completely wrong. This film took a unique twist on the concept of multiverses, and turned it to something incredibly funny and really heartfelt. Michelle Yeoh in the leading role gave the best performance of the year so far along with Ke Huy Quan. It is a shame that this one will most likely get lost in the shuffle next award season because it is going to be hard for anything to top this. This reason that this film works so well, is that it resonates with people in such away that they see themselves on the screen. The main characters are going through the same personal struggles that so many others have, and when you can connect with characters in this way it makes the film 10 times better and 10 times more impactful. Don't sleep on this one because it has the potential to be the film of the year.

An incredible, brilliant, clever, hilarious movie that had our whole theater screaming and gasping and laughing together. Ignore the comments that rant about the societal progress or the movie being hard to follow - it isn't. It's fresh and creative and absolutely worth seeing.
I can't believe how much I adored this film, the best piece of media I have experienced & possibly a contender for (If not) my favorite movie. I can't recommend it enough
One of the best movies I have ever seen and the only movie I cried in theatres for. It has a truly deeply touching story and extraordinary visuals! I would wholeheartedly recommend it  :))))

I've never seen anything like it. By the time the credits started rolling, my emotions felt like they had gone through a heavy wash at high speed for seven hours. I cried multiple times for completely different, always unexpected reasons. The film is an unparalleled masterpiece.

Truly the worst movie I have ever seen in my life. My sister and I walked out the theater along with a few more people. We all joked that the filmmakers purposely made the movie as bad as humanly possible for an experiment.
Epic. Destined to be a cult movie!

Went into this blind like I do with most A24 films, so I wasn't really sure what to expect. The way they transported you through the many bizarre multiverses was unique. The studio really nailed that aspect of the movie. But overall the story wasn't that interesting to me. I really didn't care what happened, I just stayed for the visual gems. 

This definitely wasn't a kid friendly movie as there are some adult themed scenes which didn't really add anything to the film.  I'm not sure if it's a movie I would watch again but I definitely enjoyed it the first time around for what it was. Not my favorite A24 film by a long shot.

I was blown away by Michelle Yeoh. I have always respected her potential as an actor, but this movie far exceeded my expectations of what she was capable of. To the credit of the filmmakers, writers, and actors, I could have watched a movie with these characters just trying to survive and save their family business WITHOUT the multiverse sci-fi elements. Meaning that the film did an excellent job of establishing characters that the audience really cares about BEFORE jumping into the action (Disney, please take notes here). Finally, although this film touches on social justice issues, it doesn't beat you over the head with them, which is actually a productive way to build the empathy needed for cultural change.
What did I just watch?
A comedic commentary on the meaning of life with stunning visuals and relatable characters.
One of the most amazing movies I have ever seen. I have never cried so hard (from laughter and from emotion) in my life.

it was long. but we saw Evelyn developed and made new decisions on the relationship around her, the husband, the father, the daughter. Especially like the part where the women are the most powerful in this multi-universe. production design is cool, choreography is cool. like the story, so anti-male: the bad guy is not to destroy, the solution is not to win over. How cool this is! R rated humor is nice as well. it is clear the storywriters know about the stereotypes towards their culture and show with creativity: man, you underestimate us, never so simple. How cool this is! if you couldnt at least enjoy it, then you are too uptight, work on the  open mindedness a bit.

The alphabet gang definitely had their shout outs all throughout the movie. Inappropriate for children for sure. Strong sexual themes and showing them plainly on screen. Lots of new age stuff and pushing evolution theory hard, but the actors played their parts well. The colors were bright and fun. The action scenes were pretty good.
Simple one of the greatest films I’ve ever seen.

Fantastic! So refreshing to see actual filmmaking talent in Hollywood after suffering so much pablum. I didn't research much before seeing it and have to admit was overexcited to see Ke Huy Quan acting again- when I realized who it was on the screen I yelled, "Yeah! Short Round!" So happy to see him back in the game, and he was incredible in this role. Michelle Yeoh was also PERFECTLY cast. I never knew she had such comic timing but she had me choking with laughter. This was a VERY fun movie. Very well done!

This movie is incredible on so many levels. A24 continues to deliver incredible, fresh and absolutely unique sci-fi and horror films that are just visually stunning. 

Both equally beautiful and visually stunning as it is philosophical this movie is much more than a trippy sci-fi movie but also tackles what it takes to reconcile an estranged family under enormous economic trouble. 

Also you cant help but love the costuming, production design and the satirical take on the traditional kung fu movie (without being too on the nose like "balls of furry" or "Kung Pow" 

This is just one of those films that you have to see but its far too complicated to explain. File under similar films like "Being John Malcovich" "Sunshine of the Eternal Mind" "Science of Sleep" and maybe even a little "Amile" but with a sci-fi, Kung fu, action bent. 

Again too hard to explain. Just go see it. Run (or Verse jump) to the nearest place that is still playing it even if it means paying a premium to watch at home.
Best movie of 2022 so far !!! This movie has everything, action, heart, comedy - it was an absolute joy to watch.
it was a silly movie yet with a deep message and some stupid but funny moments

I watched this in the cinema. The cinema was empty with just about five people but it was a weekday and quite late. I checked the ratings and sway high ratings on IMDB a which I usually agree with so watched the film. Rotten Tomato reviews I take with a Pinch of salt  as,90% of the time I disagree with the ratings and I'm a regular film buff. Mention a film and I've probably seen it but I feel people on IMDB are more mature and know more about film. 

Anyway, back to the film. I have no idea how the film ended because I walked out. I gave it a chance and sat through more than an hour but I could not tolerate it anymore. Suffice to say I've not walked out of a film for many years. I watch a film just about every week or two weeks depending on what is on. 

To be honest with you I have absolutely no idea how this film got such a great review. Clearly I was watching another film because I was so bored. Then again I don't agree with a,lot of reviews out there. The trailer is a good indicator of what to expect most of the time. Reviews are a bit hit and miss because everyone has their own personal taste. 

I think the world changed after covid in a very big way. More than people think. Marvel films are really bad right now but still getting rave reviews and I don't understand why. It's like people just don't recognise a good film anymore, this film is no exception. 

In my opinion avoid this film. There is absolutely nothing that makes it worth watching. No humour, weak story,m o special affects. The acting was pretty good but I think that's it.
This movie was fantastic. It has action and emotion. Good story overall. Best movie of the year
Mi favorita del año❤️

While visually impressive and pretty funny at times, the family drama never really lands for me, especially when paired with some of the corniest dialogue of the year. Still definitely worth a watch though, even if it has been overpraised and overhyped.

Completely mindblown after this movie. Somehow, everything inside this movie works perfectly, even if it shouldn't. It' a risky and absurd film that doesn't exactly fit one genre; comedy, drama, sci-fi, action, all mushed perfectly together to create a mindbending journey regarding a mother and her relationships with her family. 

Since the very fist scene, where the directors quickly introduce us to everyone in a non-stop rush; they put us in Evelyn's shoes, where her daughter is there, her husband, the laundry, the job, the father... To Evelyn that feels like everything is happening, everywhere and all at the same time. And just a bit later, everything, everywhere and all at the same is indeed happening to her. (And that's exactly how I felt during the movie, in a really good way)

It's an insane trip, that everyone should see in cinemas. I entered the theater with high expectations, and still left completely spechlees. This is the type of movie that, while you're watching it, you just know that it's something special. It sticks with you forever and It quickly become one of my all time favorites.

Possibly the best movie I've ever seen. Brilliant story, concept, characters, visuals and execution, with a very meaningful and emotional message, set in a very unusual scenario. The only negative I can say about this movie is only that I wish it elaborated more on the nature of the multiverse, but the way they presented it was very well done nonetheless. I can't fully express how impactful and moving this movie truly was, I urge everyone reading this comment to give it a chance.
One of the best movies of all time.
i have never consistently cried throughout a movie like i have this one. i have also never felt more represented in a film than in this one. its has it all. rocks. raccoons. mitski.
The movie sucked. We watched this in the movie theater and I almost fell asleep. -1000/10. Do not recommend at all.
Family, forgiveness, acceptance, love, friendship, possibilities....  There isn't any one word or way to explain this charming, thought-provoking, film that will take thru the multiverse and beyond.
Worst movie in the history of film making! Not sure why it is on cinema!
Best movie I’ve seen in years.
Fascinating, challenging, funny, and gorgeous. The costumes, makeup, cinematography, and acting were all so incredible, and the script was a truly novel idea that was explored in such a personal way.
Folks, you overestimated this movie. Here are very banal philosophical reflections, wrapped in a colorful wrapper of the multiverse.

The definitive trip through the multiverse that lives up to its name. At first I thought it'd be a reserved slow burn but it quickly flies off the rails in the best way. Stunning, high concept, and heartfelt to the extent where I truly do not know how they managed to pull this off. This feels like the type of conceptual film someone could imagine partially but couldn't quite  communicate to someone else, let alone make it real or make it make sense. But here we are, yet another modern classic.

The humor was rough, along the lines of a freshman frat party.  But it took Hugh Everett's multiverse theory, Nitche's nihilistic worldview, and the angst of today's youth and wove them into a therapeutic story.  It has some strong acting performances and good camera work.  In the end, chaos and emptiness are weighed against relationships and the good moments in life, the ones that matter.

One of the best films I've ever seen! Everytime it strayed into the weird and wacky, it was pulled back by the heartwarming and truly beautiful story and characters. It had me in tears one second and in fits of laughter the next. Watch it in its entirety, you won't regret it!

I cried, I related, I laughed, I love this film so much!!! Recommending it to everyone ;_; holy shit that was both mind-blowing amazing and so so emotional and wholesome and i- I think I'm gonna need a good lie down. Exactly what I needed thank you ;_;

One of the most wild but heartwarming movies I came by in 2022. I really loved how the plot played throughout the film with Evelyn coming in contact with all these universes where she uses them to fight those people and patch up the relationships she has with them.

Aesthetically, cool. I liked the parts where the same emotion/idea was represented different ways in different universes. Ex: an argument (in a different universe) is a kung-fu fight, or a blood splatter is a burst of confetti. But I think this movie has the same problem as other "limitless universe jumping" movies (ex: Millennium Actress), where the plots of some universes don't make sense on their own. Like, if you looked at only the tax paperwork universe plot, it's weird. The IRS agent gets *punched*, but then just forgives her.
Worse movie ever, I would not recommend even if it was free
What an amazing film! So well done. The effects, story, cinematography, etc was just excellent. A little strange but a definite must see.

Very funny, very creative, and ultimately heart-warming. Though it's technically a science fiction film, it's really a film about relationships, family dynamics and personal fulfillment. A great well-written adventure.

4.5 for me. Really loved this film. It's so refreshingly creative I'm still a little shocked it even got made! A film that deals with multiverse battles, the fate of every universe, yet at its heart is about the bond between family and loving each other for who they are. Witty, bonkers, heartfelt, visually wonderful and strong performances from the cast.
We need more movies like this - a memorable mix of heart and insanity that will keep it in your psyche for months.
Greatest film ever made in the history of cinema, rivaled only by the godfather and citizen kane.
One of my favourite movies of all time. It does everything right, while doing EVERYTHING at the same time.

The movie's answer to the nihilistic antagonist's point of nothing matters is a weak response of "just be kind". Of course being on a major streaming network the lesbian couple and accepting grandfather had to be shoe horned in. Occasional crude moments for the sake of being vulgar do not have the humor they were intended to. The movie shines in its ridiculous moments when it does not take itself seriously such as with racacoony, and the ending does have some touching moments between the husband and wife. Overall average movie, ok to watch once but would not watch again.
Opened my eyes to life in general. Life is to short to worry about the small stuff.

I really had high hopes for this movie before watching it but it's safe to say it did not come close to any of my expectations. I mean I guess the hidden concept is pretty good and the whole meaning behind it but I feel like the movie was really spoiled by how stupid it was. It was just so strange and weird. I thought the whole multiverse thing would tie back to it being like a dream or something and make it a life lesson for the main character but nope. It was just...not a movie I liked.

This is one of the most incredible films I have ever seen. A maximalist absurdist masterpiece. The cinematography, writing, VFX, choreography, acting, soundtrack -- all top of the line. Some of what is accomplished in this film is nothing short of mind-blowing. The story told here and the themes presented moved me to my core. It was executed masterfully, and I was deeply affected by it. The film is a perfect allegory for what it's like to live with depression. It also defies genre classification; it's comedy, action, sci-fi, romance, drama, thriller, tragedy -- all rolled into one. There are some bold and over the top choices made in this movie that won't land with everyone, but they sure as hell landed with me. Metaphors and allegories galore, everything said and done seems to have multiple meanings. Re-watchability is very high. This film is poetry in motion, a feast for the eyes and soul. I left the theater feeling like I would have paid twice as much for what I'd just experienced. Highly recommend watching, and going in with as little knowledge as possible. 10/10

A wildly ambitious and ambitiously weird movie, this takes the multiverse concept to new heights in the strangest way.  Presenting a normal person confronted with the multiverse is already a fun idea, but then we are presented with writer/director Daniels signature brand of oddness in how they deal with the multiverse and it's pretty fantastic.  Does it all work?  Does it all make sense?  No, but does it all need to?  Not really.  Its emotional core is strong, its humor is solid, and its ambition is through the roof.

A few scenes that were just a tiny bit awkward to watch with the family. This movie really drives home the meaning that every single decision in our life has an affect on our future. It also explores the popular idea of alternate universes and timelines. There were so many messages in this film it's hard to just highlight one but I think the one that resonated the most with me was Joy's cry for help for her mother's understanding and perhaps acceptance. When we grow up, sometimes we don't want to hear what our parents consider "right", sometimes we just want to know that our parents will be there to support us no what matter what.

It was as if the filmmakers thought that any martial arts/time travel movie with good visuals would be enough to satisfy the audience. Story progression matters. Every time I thought the main character was about to have a revelation brought about by the mayhem, it was the same revelation: she works too hard, her life is going nowhere and she doesn't see things through.  WE GET IT! Silliness is fine, if it isn't just random. Martial arts with bloody dildos isn't inspired, it's lazy writing. And the movie is waaaaaay tooooooo loooooong. Big disappointment

The visual effects were flat-out jaw-dropping and the costume designers deserve a huge raise. This is the craziest movie I’ve ever scene and absolutely loved it. Wildly creative and heartwarming. Among all the nonsense, the writers did a perfect job of still incorporating an important and realistic view at the life of a Chinese-American family. The message really hit close to home. Everything Everywhere All At Once is a must-see for everyone.

It's brilliantly inventive and fun.

The Hitchiker's Guide to the Galaxy is a great book. It also inspired a glut of of art-school string theorists. Their latest offering is "EEAAO".
I hoped that this brand of humanist pop-science nihilism would die when Rick and Morty was cancelled. Visually overstimulating, painfully quirky, and philosophically vapid - like watching Neil Degrasse Tyson's Cosmos on molly. 
The strong direction - mainly relating to the lead performances and consistent tone - counterbalances its irritating script, but not enough to save it. 
This could've been a great family drama with a healthy dash of existentialism. Sadly, Daniels' writing is too immature to maturely engage with science or philosophy. I guess it's easier to beat conventional existential morality to death with a dildo.

Expressive, eccentric and cathartic. Everything Everywhere All At Once is the embodiment of the magic of cinema, and a prime example of fresh originality that modern Hollywood is capable of exploring but is so often too afraid to pursue. The sound design had me on my toes, the editing tore me from my own reality into many others, and the heart-tugging themes across the beautiful chaos were nothing short of breathtaking to experience. It is both hilarious and dramatic, with a handful of questionable juvenile moments that are purely subjective to your taste, but in its entirety, is still weird and wonderful. This is what movie magic looks, sounds and feels like.

As an asian who studied psych and is fascinated by discourse in consumerism, it was definitely a relatable movie. I had a lot of fun combing through all the metaphors and symbolisms in the movie. It reminded me of my first trip to Costco where I was both overwhelmed and in awe of the selection there. It really was "everything, everywhere...all at once".

Overall, this movie was an indescribable experience that cannot be easily translated into words (at least for me). I was laughing, crying and wishing my teenage self could sit through the 2 hours with me. Like Evelyn/Joy, my life was a mess, but, over the years, I learned to love myself and all the people who choice to stick with me through all the guck. Life itself may be meaningless because we are so small, but life is beautiful nonetheless.

While the movie might take a lot of time and go through a lot of complex and confusing scenes, they all add up to a wholesome ending that's sure to make anyone appreciate the movie. In my opinion the best thing this movie does is find a way to explore the dynamic of family relations, and it's portrayal is more than realistic, the directors are grounded in this regard, from the precarious and   love- hate relationship Evelyn and Joy have, to the problem filled marriage between Waymond and Evelyn, surprisingly enough it even shows the anxiety Joy has in navigating loving a girl and coming out to her grandfather; that is one of the best things about this movie. The next thing I think it explores really well is the idea of free choice, (not to be pretentious but) it does make the Kierkegaardian point that anxiety is the dizziness of choice, by showing the protagonist, Evelyn, explore all the choices she ever made in her life, and how by making different choices her life led to completely different paths most of them being more successful than the life path she currently was in, and how this affects her psychologically. We then get to see the difference between her reaction to that and her daughters' reaction to finding this out, landing her daughter to arrive at the classic cosmic nihilist point "That nothing in the world matters," while this has been explored in so many classic movies and Tv Series so may times, the feel of this movie is different because for some time the characters do agree with this, until the climax of the movie happens and takes a turn in the direction of Existential Nihilism, and tries to save all the characters. This movie, at first almost seemed like Rick and Morty (which I am a fan of) but unlike it the family dynamic is more realistic, I digress. While the philosophical idea of the movie and ideas brought up are handled well, the next thing I would like to address is the sheer cinematic and directing style of the movie, the choreography, acting and emotions expressed are truly magnificent and aid towards the story telling. This is an instant classic movie in my opinion, it's not too heavy and not too light, honestly my best movie of the year. I have to admit this movie would be hard to make, it introduces so many ideas in so little time, even the way it divides the parts into three is brilliant, did I say it was a good movie again.

I haven't had a repeat viewing of a movie for several months now. This one brought me back again and again in a matter of a week. 

There is a challenge with this movie though, and that is to get through the first half of the movie without falling for it thinking some kind of a usual superhero discovering her true power and defeating a mysterious villain. It is strange that a movie truly starts after a full 90 minutes, and shows its splendor and creativity in a jam-packed 45 minutes peak that keeps on going afterwards. In the first one and a half hours though, there are parts where the pace drags, and the fight scenes repeat and distract from the movie's setup. But once you get to the 90 minute mark (Yes, it's almost specific) it becomes impossible to not enjoy every minute from there on and smile at the cleverness, creativity, emotional exploration, and not to mention fantastic visual cues.

It does of course help that both Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu were killing it. Seriously good dynamic.

WARNING: THIS REVIEW IS BEING WRITTEN BEFORE I WATCH "DOCTOR STRANGE: MULTIVERSE OF MADNESS"! A little hint for who's going to watch: don't even think to compare "Everything Everywhere All at Once" with "Swiss Army Man". There are two totally different proposals, and I confess I took a while to fully embark on the story here, while the 2016 film hooked me in the first two minutes. The beginning is a little messy and the multiverse plot is kind of sneaked into the narrative, but when the film finally consolidates its tone, it never falls, on the contrary. The universe conception here is one of the best I've ever seen, the creativity level here borders on the unbelievable (I think it can rival only "Millenium Actress" and "Spirited Away"). The concept of multiverse here is the same used in the MCU, but while at Marvel the concept is still theoretical, here we can see it in practice. There are at least six parallel stories that never run over each other and are extremely well developed (if this movie doesn't win Best Original Screenplay at the Academy Awards there's no justice in the world). I have a lot to say about the cast but this is a movie that doesn't allow spoilers. It's normal to feel that the third act is a little dragged, I felt it too, but as in "Uncut Gems", it's an understandable decision, because the rhythm is in line with what the character is feeling and the situation she is going through. I would say something about the ending but even the minor comparison can be a spoiler. In a nutshell, watch this film as soon as you can!

I would've recommended for high schoolers if not for the sex stuff thrown in. (Some audience members found those funny, but others just found it gross.) The plot itself becomes obvious for the last chunk of movie. (And it is kind of serious.)  But there are several times that you go... oh, it's still not over. A beautiful, highly creative imagination fest of pure unadulterated wackiness that still deeply resonates on a simple, personal level. This really is the Doctor Strange movie that Marvel would have made if it wasn't a bureaucratic juggernaut filled with mindless content drones, but a young bristling indie start-up with intelligent youngsters and one very old, very wise woman. At its core it's quite a simple tale of a woman coming to terms with her life, her family and herself through a combination of mindfulness and appreciation of the smaller gifts of life. This simple, but powerful theme though is presented in one of the most creative, imaginative, visually stunning ways I've ever seen on the big screen. It's a brute force attack on the senses, but oh so detailed and smooth. Like eating a rainbow and drinking a waterfall, while laying in sheets made of multi-dimensional silk. What a daring achievement. What a relieve that something like this can still reach the screen. What a pleasure to see a film that feels like a party in a bristling city on a night in which anything is possible. Go see this.

"Everything everywhere all at once" is a joy to experience.

A family, who's business is currently being investigated for tax fraud, find themselves thrown into the realm of the multiverse in order to save existence itself.  Jamie Lee Curtis is the investigator challenged to gain answers to questionable tax deductions while Michelle Yeoh ( Evelyn Wang ) is tasked with providing those answers while being distracted by her husband Waymond ( Ke Huy Quan ) jumping from universe to universe. 

What ensues is a fun filled, emotional,  SCI FI adventure that keeps the audience guessing the probable outcomes throughout. The performances of the four main actors, who juggle with very different characterisations of the family members, are magnificent. The Standout performances however are from both Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan who not only showcase their martial art skills but also highlight their fantastic comic timing as they switch between different versions of their characters in each universe they visit. 

The optimism and love the central characters show to each other as well as others contrasts so well with the cold uncaring multiverse. What this achieves is "Everything everywhere all at once " manages to deliver such an emotional uplift that it ensures the film will stay with its audience for a long time after.

"Seeking companionship in the inevitable nihilism of adult-hood." - my quick review. 

This movie is important.

This is a damn near perfect coming of age story... for adults. If you are a crier in your 30's+, be warned. Nihilism is lonely but inevitable thought progression with age. If you empathize with this/you have a brain and are watching the news and have parents, this movie will likely poke at some of your deepest insecurities (in the best way). It may point out crushing, immense fears but will quickly double-down, reassuring you that you are not alone (I've never sympathized to intensely with a rock). It is an immensely pertinent commentary on our most impactful interpersonal relationships, wrangling in comedy with compassion. Loved this movie with a first watch and it became one of my all-time favorites with a second watch. Finally, I need to say... It's hilarious. Literally laugh out loud funny. It's so emotionally poignant it's easy to forget but steel yourself for hot-dog fingers.

It was an absolute blast. Watching it in a cinema with an audience that was reacting to the movie definitely made it even better but I think I was going to love it no matter what. There is so much in this movie that I definitely need at least a few rewatches to fully appreciate it.

First off it's great. Second, it's bonkers. It's part Kung Fu movie, part superhero movie, part family drama, part comedy, part action movie, part detective movie. It has subtitles for some of it, English speaking in most of it. Everyone acting in the film is great. You've got the gorgeous Michelle Yeoh, who shows her courage by dressing and looking like a beleaguered mom, wife and laundromat owner who's thrown into a situation WAY beyond her everyday experiences. There's the adorable Stephanie Hsu who has so many crazy costume changes your head will spin. And Jamie Lee Curtis who allows herself to look ten times worse than Michelle! And of course James Hong, playing the grandfather, who's been in every movie you've ever seen.

So what's it about…? Well it's tough to sum up but in short, a lady learns there are parallel universes that are all in grave danger and she is recruited to help save them all.

It's funny, touching, exciting, crazy and weird. I loved it. And you'll never look at an everything bagel the same way again.

Finally! A multiverse movie with imagination, soul, and delightful absurdity! This is art in its highest form. Beneath its dazzling surface, this movie teases out deep questions about modern life.

Until recently, all of human history was a struggle for survival. Today, our lives are so comfortable that we are faced with a completely different kind of problem: too many choices.

Is our multitude of choices a blessing, or a curse?

Life in a hunter-gatherer society was nasty, brutish, and short. Our path in life was mostly predetermined: just try to survive and reproduce. But the few good moments could be fully savored and enjoyed, because that's all there was.

We evolved to survive as hunter-gatherers, so we are maladapted for modern society. With all of our survival needs met, our biggest challenge is to wrestle with our own vestigial cognitive biases. 

With so many life paths available to us, our cognitive bias focuses on the drawbacks of the choices we make, while conversely focusing on the benefits of the choices we didn't make.

Should I have chosen the other University? Did I choose the right course of study? Is this really my most self-actualizing career path? Should I have married the other person I dated? Do I want to have children, and if so how many?

The presence of these choices is an indicator of a pretty good life.

But if we get stuck doting on choices not taken, it's harder to appreciate the positive aspects of the life we chose. In this way, having many choices is a burden, because when the path we chose turns out to be imperfect, we blame ourselves for not having chosen differently.

In reality–in every possible reality, there are always imperfections. If we can learn to accept that every choice, even the best choice, has drawbacks, then we can free ourselves to more deeply appreciate the benefits of the path we find ourselves on presently.

Go see this movie while it's still in theaters!

It's hard to give an objective opinion on this movie other than that this masterpiece will be remembered as one of the most exciting, unique, endearing, philosophical and influential movies of 2022, if not all time, giving each and every one of us on this tiny blue dot in the ever-expanding universe something we didn't know we needed, everything everywhere all at once.

You will laugh. You will cry. You will cry and laugh at the same time. You will smile. You will frown and smile at the same time. You will smile, frown, laugh and then cry and more. You will experience it all. You will go through trough everything everywhere all at once.

Here's how this movie talked to me, personally.

The movie couldn't have come out at a better time. The last few years have been tough for all of us. It feels as though we've been served all the bad everything everywhere all at once. Not a single stone has been left unturned. After the last few years of a long, wild and scary rollercoaster of worldwide struggles, this movie comes out to remind us that nothing matters, but not in the extreme nihilistic way you'd probably expect.

It teaches us that there's beauty in nihilism to be found. We just need to make an effort to search for it. It reminds us that our little struggles or big world problems don't matter. 

They say that your life flashes before your eyes upon your death, reminding you of everything everywhere all at once - your life, the joys of life and the struggles of life, things you may have long forgotten, decisions you made, both good and bad, and past experiences, both positive and negative. Some may experience regret but most certainly hope to experience happiness and feel a sense of fulfilment at the end of their journey, as they get closure to the light at the end of the tunnel (bagel). 

If this is all true, then, to me, this magical movie is the embodiment of that experience, with a little twist. It pulls us out of the void of the bagel. It pulls us away from the light at the end of the tunnel back into our bodies, creating a much stronger sense of self and giving us a second chance at our life. It teaches us that at the end of the day, it's the people closest to us, our family and friends, and our relationships with them are the only thing that matters. It gives us a second chance and an opportunity to experience and flash through our lives, everything everywhere all at once, and go back and make peace with ourselves, who we are, and amend relationships with the people that matter the most, our family and friends, and start truly and genuinely appreciate what we have so that when the time comes, there's no space for regret, but joy! There is not a single negative thing about this movie and this whole experience, not even one thing to nitpick.

Now, I think that some people may take points away for the length of the movie, but for me personally, length is rarely an issue, especially if the people behind the movie have evidently this much genuine passion, love and respect for the arts of movie making and have put this much blood, sweat and effort into it. And especially if the people and the movie are as bold, unique, resourceful and creative, willing to compromise and explore interesting ideas and serve them to us. Extremely talented, resourceful and creative artists, visionaries and risk-takers such as "The" Daniels and their crew of world-class actors such as "The" Michelle Yeoh, "The" Stephanie Hsu, "The" Ke Huy Quan and "The" Jamie Lee Curtis and "The" wonderful stunt people, SFX and practical effects crew must be celebrated. ("not to their recent interview")

I wish, no, I beg everyone to go and support this movie so that Hollywood starts making more movies like this one. Hence, I wouldn't dare to take away anything from them. Definitely not because they try to entertain me for 10 more minutes with an actual,  well-thought-out and complicated piece of art that was challenging to make. And most definitely not in a world where random 15-60 second videos are overtaking the world of entertainment and the world's attention.

Despite the hype, I do not believe this movie is about an unlikely savior of the universe of universes. Rather, it is an exploration of one woman's struggle to maintain loving relationships with her daughter, husband, and father in the face of life's relentless drive towards chaos and mediocrity. I saw the multiverse sideshow as reflective of her own regrets at the choices not taken, how she wished to impose her desires on those of her family, and how little she actually knew about theirs.

The extended metaphor goes on much too long, with a few totally unnecessary sidetracks. For example, a good ten minutes is devoted to the man with a raccoon on his head. All of this could have been left out, and the film still would have kept its narrative arc and made its points. The Daniels had a lot of fun riffing on kung-fu movies, film noir, and a raft of science fiction from the past (Matrix, anyone?) But a few hot-dog fingers and slow-motion butt jokes go a long way, and could have been trimmed a bit

With more discipline and a sharper eye towards what they were trying to do, these guys could have had the next Groundhog Day or Ghostbusters. Instead, we're left with an overlong but pleasant evening's entertainment for the intellectually savvy.

I must have seen a different movie than everyone else.  This movie was a mess with a lot of disconnected scenes. The supposedly unifying theme was the multiverse or really the many worlds theory.  The idea being that every choice we make involves the universe splitting and our histories (and ourselves) existing in both universes one where the choice was made and one where it wasnt. 
But the movie doesnt really show this. Instead it presents a chaotic and confusing theory and method of suddenly switching universes. Some of the innumerable kung fu fighting scenes are funny, at least if youre  an 8th grader. Bad guys trying to land butt first on objects to have the objects go up their rectums. Or women fighting by swinging over sized penis shaped dildos at each other. The audience laughed at these scenes. 
I found myself waiting and waiting for the movie to end. None of the other people in the theater seemed to like the movie—except the scenes where Jamie Lee Curtis was an IRS auditor whod turn into a scary terrorist a few times during the movie. She was good in this role.
