Getting a ten from me and being one of my favorite films had every chance and the first work of the Daniels - an eccentric and young duo of directors with a crazy and original style. But Swiss Knife Man didn't make it to the end and only got a nine from me, which doesn't stop me from considering it an extremely original and funny film that I can recommend to many. However, after 6 years, the Daniels were able to beat me to perfection.

The very title of their new film fully describes the essence - it really is everything, everywhere and at once. A riot of fantasy, absurd humor and sci-fi at the level of the best Rick and Morty series is beyond description - this is what you need to see. Doctor Strange will have to sweat a lot to surpass the local concept of the multiverse and especially madness.

This film has all the ingredients to keep me satisfied: a surreal farcical comedy, also a great drama about the generation gap and the idea of ​​​​the value of the family, the most difficult script that Nolan would envy, its excellent execution, strong acting (Jamie Lee was especially pleased Curtis, who is not immediately recognizable here) and a wonderful message, even some kind of philosophy of its own. It's a movie that combines hilarious jokes, selective action, and at the same time raises questions about the meaning of life, the universe, and all that.

Amazing. I am delighted. I think the multiverse is the future of sci-fi in cinema, and Everything, Everywhere, All at Once is a pioneer in that. And the Daniels, I'm sure, will still show the world a lot of goodness. Very inspired by them. I'm looking forward to their next works (it's a pity that they come out so rarely) and I advise everyone to go to "Everything, everywhere and at once". Of course, the oversaturation of this film and the intensity of the absurd may seem excessive to someone (in my session, for example, people just left the hall and I heard that this happens often), but such a movie should be given a chance. This is truly something special and amazing.

Astounding that Dr Strange in the multiverse of madness gets rubbished as the inferior of these two multiverse movies. I am not saying Dr Strange is a masterpiece but while watching Everything, Everywhere, All at once you will start to feel it comparatively is. Such a boring movie, lacking a good story. There may be a bare bones good plot here but it is lost under the poor narrative choices and the decision to be arty and bizarre at the sacrifice of a compelling, interesting, and coherent movie. I will take a more traditional styled film over one that tries to scew conventions at the detriment of producing a decent end product. Self indulgent pretentiousness at its worse.

This film is astounding.

Daniels have managed to give the concept of the multiverse (a trope already starting to overextend itself) new life and new purpose on film, which is no small feat. Wrapped up in this insanely frenetic and propulsive film is a story that centers on family, catharsis, love, kindness, violence, nihilism, acceptance, friendship, hope, loss, and… buttplugs.

Reading that last sentence, you might get the wrong impression that this movie feels somewhat unfocused or too widespread to connect all of those dots. But like the movie's multiverse, they all stem from one single point in the narrative, and that focus aids in creating a story that flits easily between each emotional beat Daniels have lined up for the audience.

The main character of Evelyn Wang is the central focus of the story, and Michelle Yeoh is the absolute perfect actor to play her. This is undoubtedly her best work in years, not only showcasing her still incredible prowess as an on-screen fighter, but the depth of her ability to bring characters to life—sometimes with laser-focused nuance, sometimes with wild hilarity, and sometimes with unabashed heart. She breathes the air of this film and it's story so easily.

And the rest of the cast—Stephanie Hsu as Joy, Ke Huy Quan as Waymond, James Hong as Gong, and Jaimie Lee Curtis as Dierdre—are so perfectly cast it's impossible to watch this film and not be bowled over by the sheer talent they have. Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu are particularly effecting in their roles as Evelyn's husband and daughter, respectively, and they have moments in the third act so full of genuine honesty and emotion that it brought me to tears.

Also notable is the unbelievably good stunt choreography, the special effects, and the editing. The fight scenes are married with brilliant practical effects and CGI (done by just FIVE people!) and together, they call back to the best of Hong Kong and American action cinema—from Jackie Chan's entire career of frantic-seeming choreography, to Yeoh's own masterful display in ‘Crouching Tiger', to Keanu Reeves in ‘The Matrix', and many, many others. It's a love letter to movement and action, and it feels so good to watch unfold. All of this is held together with some of the best editing I've ever seen in a film. With pacing that ratchets back and forth between methodical to otherworldly, Paul Rogers' has done a perfect job marrying each of the emotional story beats and action set pieces into a cohesive and eminently watchable work of art.

Lastly, the film looks amazing. It's lush and beautiful, with shifting colors and textures mixed into a kaleidoscopic experience. Larkin Seiple deserves every accolade for making multiple universes feel grounded and somehow real.

I loved this movie. It has a way of worming into you with its weirdness and its everything, everywhereness and, once it does, what it has to say tends to hit very hard and very fast. I found myself crying at scenes featuring the oddest things: Rocks with googly-eyes. Hot-dog fingers. Black hole bagels. But it makes sense somehow, and that weirdness only proves that the central themes of the film are so strong and so true to life that nothing Daniels throw at you detracts from them; together, it all builds to a stronger, more effecting climatic finish that left me so glad to have experienced it.

Go see this film, and go see it in as full a theater as you can. Half the delight is watching something beautiful with other people who see the same thing, all at once.

I saw one trailer for this movie I knew it was a must-see and MAN was I right! Everything Everywhere All at Once did everything and nothing that I expected. I was excited to see a movie tackle a multiverse scenario and this one did it in a way so fluid and believable it took my breath away. It went from full-on action to genuine horror to intensely emotional to utterly ridiculous in minutes, and I love every second of it. Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, and Ke Huy Quan all gave such beautiful, heartwarming, and epically insane performances I laughed, cried, and laughed again. The central theme of the movie is what seriously surprised me. I never thought a silly multiverse movie would tackle such a heavy topic so effectively. Who knew a scene where two characters were rocks could make me emotional but it did! Never in a hundred years did I think I would enjoy this movie as much as I did. Overall, this movie is amazing simple as that! Don't take my word for it though, WATCH IT!

Highly recommend!! I got to say this is the best movie I have watched this year!! This film is based on a typical first-generation Chinese immigrant family, living in a cramped apartment, running a laundry room that is almost broken, trying to merge into American society but always keeping their cultural background. Marital problems, generational problems, cultural differences, and tax troubles literally make their life worse. The director used an absurd narrative skill, especially multiple universals, to tell a touching and reasonable story. I strongly resonate with this story since we share the same cultural background. As a Chinese girl, also a single daughter in my family, I totally understand the parent-child conflict presented in the film. Our thoughts, feelings, and opinions don't make sense to our parents in some ways as the rapid changing and development both in China and America, but they are always there no matter what and support us for no reason. They always try their best to give us the best. "It doesn't make sense but I am there."
I was also touched by another thing that the director wanna deliver, "What if". What if Wang didn't abandon all they had in Hong Kong and come to the US from the very beginning. Maybe she won't need to accept that her daughter is dating another girl and deal with the shit like tax report. 
Illusion is always perfect since it isn't real. 
What if I stay in China? IDK......
I am so happy to see there are more high-quality Asian cast movies in Hollywood. We are no longer invisible or forced to present our culture under the white gaze in movies.

Note too  while some critics raved many of the best critics (Variety, New Yorker , The Guardian, Reel Film) didn't at all  while even many of the apparently  'Fresh' reviews listed  here contain comments like 'silly and  sophomoric...it's hard to know what to make of it' (Washington Post). That particular review,  giving  it two and a half stars so hardly very 'fresh; I would argue,  is actually pretty fair. if you like dumb frat comedy you're going to love this but otherwise forget it.

It was awesome to see a movie that is engaged with some pretty original, fantastical scifi plotting that does not center white people or, for that matter, middle or upper class people. I found the frenetic depiction of the multiverse to be a bit exhausting and distracting, as I first watched this, and I wasn't sure that I liked the tonal juxtaposition of that and the basic emotional conflict. I also thought that the reaction to this movie in my immediate social circle was weirdly over the top positive in a way that made me itch, and I wondered if this movie was kind of a flash in the pan that no one would want to think about in two years. Possibly, but what I came back to is the sense in which the movie is about roads not taken and how to be emotionally present your life despite resentments, regrets, and deflation. That aspect of it has stuck with me enough that I think it was more successful than I initially gave it credit for.
The better of the two multiverse movies that have been recently released.

Funny, beautiful cinematography, fantastic acting, amazing fight scenes, brilliant editing and so so heartfelt. I found myself crying not only at the emotional scenes, but because I thought scenes were just so well done. I saw this movie on a Saturday, then immediately bought another round of tickets for Sunday. Seeing a character like Joy feeling so numb & hopeless, and finding a way out of that feeling hit so hard with me, and I can't thank the creators of this movie enough for putting that feeling on screen. It's been a long time since I felt so much joy, relief and emotional release coming out of a movie theatre. If anyone who worked on this movie happens to come across this review of mine, thank you, thank you, thank you for making this movie. It's easily one of my all-time favourites, and something I know I'm going to be watching 1000 more times. Thank you.

The first hour of this was strange but intriguing as well as funny. The next hour was god awful. I fell asleep three times. It was an hour of "being artsy just to be artsy", with very little storytelling. The last twenty minutes was the only worthwhile part of the film honestly. This could have been really good but it was just desperate to be eccentric and SUPER repetitive and redundant. I'm not sure how many times we need to be told the same story to understand the depth of the trauma between the main characters but apparently it's like 100 times in 100 different realities. The actual conflict of the story is a pretty simple one and yes it is relatable but the hours of theatrics was not necessary to get the point across.

People who know me well, know I love movies. I always have from a very young age. I have seen thousands of movies in my life. It's always been hard to choose one I love best above others. I usually have a top five. Until now. This is my absolute favorite movie, and I doubt another will take it's place. It will make you feel so many emotions. It will open your mind to things you overlook. It will make sense of things you couldn't understand. It will heal pain in your heart. It will make you laugh and cry. You will take it all in and want to be a better person in the end. You will be glad you experienced a film this genius, this deep, and this real. It is a masterpiece of film making. If you don't "get it", then you aren't ready to. Those that do, it will open your third eye, even if it's a googly eye. I loved every second of this film. It is everything, everywhere, all at once.

After 2016's Daniel Radcliff farting corpse film introduced us to the quirky inventive madness of Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, a pair of co-writers/directors known collectively as Daniels, they have upped their game with their follow-up, a multiverse film that's as good as, if not better than, what Marvel can muster, but on a fraction of their budget. The always fantastic Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan are the Wangs who run a family laundromat being audited by Jamie Lee Curtis's IRS agent. Throw in Stephanie Hsu's lesbian daughter and James Hong's traditional Gong Gong and what we have is a well-observed Asian-American intergenerational family drama dressed up with science-fiction bells and whistles and what's technically classified as fairly lo-fi special effects, though they're no less effective for it. With the rules of the multiverse and increasingly ridiculous instructions for jumping between them subversively dispensed with in the duration of an elevator ride, their screenplay manages to just about contain itself within its own logic and make it makes sense, and with that exposition out of the way, the rest is a fast-paced kinetic joyride (with an exhausted editor afterwards) through alternate universes where a brilliant and gamed cast are given ample opportunities to play distinctively different characters while the Daniels lobe everything from cinematic riffs on Ratatouille, 2001, and naturally HK cinema as represented by the extremities that are Jackie Chan action comedy and Wong Kai Wai's melancholic romanticism to random surrealism like hotdog fingers and subtitled rocks onto the screen. If admittedly it drags a little towards the end as it piles on very conventional and sentimental cliches to concoct its crowd-pleasing love-is-the-answer ending, it remains bizarrely entertaining, visually arresting and narratively chaotic and bonkers all at once, and I can't wait to see it again.
